metadata.title: First Interactive App Tutorial
metadata.description: Build a counter app step by step, learning core concepts along the way

sections.overview:
This tutorial walks you through building an interactive counter application from
scratch. You will learn how to import primitives, manage state with React hooks, handle
user input with Pressable, and style your UI with flexbox properties. By the end you
will have a working app with increment and decrement buttons, styled with colors and
spacing.

examples.title: Step 1 - Create the Project
examples.code:
ilovereact init counter-app
cd counter-app

examples.title: Step 2 - Basic Counter (src/App.tsx)
Step 3 - Add Buttons
Step 4 - Lint and Screenshot
examples.code:
# Run the static linter to catch layout errors
ilovereact lint

# Take a screenshot to verify the visual result
ilovereact screenshot --output /tmp/counter.png

# Build for distribution
ilovereact build dist:love

criticalRules: Every Text node MUST have an explicit fontSize.
The root container MUST use width: '100%', height: '100%' -- not flexGrow: 1.
Row Boxes need explicit width for justifyContent to work.
Use template literals (backticks) for dynamic text: {`${count}`}, not mixed
children like {count} which creates multiple text nodes.
Always run `ilovereact lint` after modifying components.
seeAlso: quick-start.txt - Abbreviated version of this tutorial
11-troubleshooting/common-errors.txt - If something does not render correctly

metadata.title: Getting Started
metadata.description: Hub page for all getting-started topics in iLoveReact

sections.overview:
Welcome to iLoveReact. This section covers everything you need to go from zero to a
running application. Whether you are targeting Love2D, a terminal emulator, Neovim, or
any other supported platform, the fundamentals are the same: install the toolchain,
scaffold a project, write React components, and build.

Start with the philosophy document to understand what iLoveReact is and how it differs
from browser-based React. Then follow the installation guide, run through the quick
start, and build your first interactive app.

examples.code:
01-getting-started/
  philosophy.txt   - What iLoveReact is and how it thinks
  installation.txt - Prerequisites and setup steps
  quick-start.txt  - 5-minute path to a running app
  first-app.txt    - Build a counter app step by step

seeAlso: quick-start.txt - Fastest path to running code
first-app.txt - Guided tutorial for your first interactive app

metadata.title: Installation Guide
metadata.description: Prerequisites and step-by-step setup for the iLoveReact monorepo and CLI

sections.overview:
iLoveReact is an npm workspaces monorepo. The core framework runs on Node.js for builds
and development tooling. The Love2D target additionally requires the Love2D runtime and
a compiled QuickJS shared library. This guide walks through every step from a fresh
clone to a verified installation.

Grid targets (terminal, ComputerCraft, Neovim, Hammerspoon, AwesomeWM) only need
Node.js. The Love2D target needs the full toolchain.
sections.api:
Prerequisites:
  - Node.js 18+ and npm
  - Love2D 11+ (for Love2D target only)
  - make + gcc (for QuickJS compilation, Love2D target only)
  - git

examples.title: Full Installation (All Targets)
examples.code:
# 1. Clone the repository
git clone <repo-url> && cd react-love

# 2. Install npm dependencies (workspaces monorepo)
npm install

# 3. Build QuickJS shared library (needed for Love2D target)
#    Clones quickjs-ng and compiles libquickjs.so
make setup

# 4. Propagate source-of-truth files to CLI runtime
#    Copies lua/*.lua, packages/shared/, packages/native/, libquickjs.so
#    into cli/runtime/ so the CLI can scaffold projects
make cli-setup

# 5. Link the CLI globally
cd cli && npm link && cd ..

# 6. Verify the installation
ilovereact help

examples.title: Minimal Installation (Grid Targets Only)
examples.code:
# Grid targets (terminal, cc, nvim, hs, awesome) do not need Love2D or QuickJS

# 1. Clone and install
git clone <repo-url> && cd react-love
npm install

# 2. Build a terminal demo directly
npm run build:terminal-demo

# 3. Run it
node examples/terminal-demo/dist/main.js

platformNotes.Love2D:
- Install Love2D 11+ from https://love2d.org or your package manager.
- On Linux: `sudo apt install love` or download the AppImage.
- On macOS: `brew install love` or download from love2d.org.
- The `make setup` step compiles libquickjs.so which requires a C compiler (gcc or clang).
platformNotes.Terminal:
- Requires a terminal with truecolor support (most modern terminals).
- No additional system dependencies beyond Node.js.
platformNotes.ComputerCraft:
- Requires a running Minecraft instance with CC: Tweaked mod.
- The WebSocket bridge connects to the CC terminal.
platformNotes.Neovim:
- Requires Neovim 0.7+ with the `neovim` npm package.
- Communication via stdio.

criticalRules: Always run `make cli-setup` after pulling framework changes. This propagates
source-of-truth files into the CLI runtime directory.
Never edit files in cli/runtime/ directly. They are overwritten by make cli-setup.
The `npm link` step in cli/ must be done once to make the `ilovereact` command
available globally.
seeAlso: quick-start.txt - Create your first project after installation

metadata.title: iLoveReact Philosophy
metadata.description: Core design principles behind iLoveReact - React stripped of browser magic, rendered as raw geometry

sections.overview:
iLoveReact is React stripped of browser magic and rendered as raw geometry. There is no
DOM, no CSS cascade, no implicit sizing, no inherited font stacks, no default margins.
Every pixel on screen exists because your code explicitly put it there.

If you did not say how wide it is, it is zero. If you said grow, it grows exactly. If
you nested flex containers, you own the consequences. If text wraps, it is because you
gave it nowhere to go. This is not a browser abstraction layer. This is direct rendering
-- React's component model driving actual draw calls on real hardware.

examples.title: The Multi-Target Promise
The Rendering Pipeline
examples.code:
The data flows through a fixed pipeline on every frame:

  1. React reconciler    - Diffs your component tree, produces mutation commands
  2. Mutation commands   - JSON describing createNode, updateProps, appendChild, etc.
  3. Transport layer     - Delivers commands to the target runtime (QuickJS FFI, WebSocket, stdio, Module.FS)
  4. Layout engine       - Lua-side flexbox computes {x, y, width, height} for every node
  5. Target painter      - Draws actual pixels, characters, or API calls for the target platform

Each target has its own painter, but the reconciler, mutation protocol, and layout
engine are shared across all of them.

criticalRules: There is no implicit sizing. A Box without width and height is zero by zero.
There is no CSS cascade. Style properties do not inherit from parent to child
(except fontSize and color on nested Text nodes).
Every Text node MUST have an explicit fontSize. The linter enforces this.
flexGrow only works when the parent has a known size on the main axis.
This is NOT a browser. There are no default stylesheets, no user-agent margins,
no block/inline flow model. Everything is flexbox, always.
seeAlso: 02-architecture/layout-engine.txt - How the Lua flexbox engine works

metadata.title: 5-Minute Quick Start
metadata.description: The fastest path from installation to a running iLoveReact application

sections.overview:
This guide gets you from zero to a running iLoveReact app in five minutes. You will
scaffold a new Love2D project, edit the entry component, run it in watch mode, and
optionally produce a standalone binary. All you need is a completed installation
(see installation.txt).

examples.title: Scaffold and Run (Love2D)
examples.code:
# Scaffold a new project
ilovereact init my-app
cd my-app

# Start watch mode (rebuilds on file changes)
ilovereact dev

# In a second terminal, run Love2D
love .

examples.title: Edit src/App.tsx
Build a Standalone Binary
examples.code:
# Lint first (catches layout errors before build)
ilovereact lint

# Take a screenshot to verify layout
ilovereact screenshot --output /tmp/preview.png

# Build self-extracting Linux binary
ilovereact build dist:love

criticalRules: Always use `ilovereact init` to scaffold projects. Do not mkdir and copy manually.
Always use `ilovereact dev` for watch mode. Do not run esbuild --watch manually.
Always use `ilovereact build` for production builds. Do not run esbuild manually.
The CLI encodes correct esbuild flags, enforces lint gates, and handles runtime
file placement.
After modifying any component, run `ilovereact lint` to catch layout errors.

metadata.title: Architecture
metadata.description: Hub page for iLoveReact architecture documentation

sections.overview:
iLoveReact's architecture is a multi-stage rendering pipeline. React components are
reconciled into an instance tree, serialized as mutation commands, transported to the
target runtime, laid out by a flexbox engine, and drawn by a target-specific painter.
Each stage is independent and replaceable.

This section documents each stage in detail, from the React reconciler through the
final paint calls. Understanding this pipeline is essential for debugging layout issues,
building custom targets, or contributing to the framework.

examples.title: Section Contents
examples.code:
02-architecture/
  pipeline.txt        - End-to-end rendering pipeline overview
  reconciler.txt      - React reconciler and host config
  layout-engine.txt   - Lua-side flexbox layout engine
  transport.txt       - Transport layer (QuickJS FFI, Module.FS, WebSocket, stdio)
  painter.txt         - Target-specific painters
  source-of-truth.txt - File organization and sync pipeline

seeAlso: pipeline.txt - Start here for the big picture

metadata.title: Layout Engine
metadata.description: The Lua-side flexbox layout engine that computes positions and sizes for every node

sections.overview:
The layout engine (layout.lua) is a Lua-side flexbox implementation that runs inside the
Love2D process. After the retained tree receives mutation commands, the layout engine
walks the entire tree and computes a {x, y, w, h} rect for every node. It handles
absolute units, percentages, vw/vh viewport units, flex-grow/shrink distribution, text
wrapping via Love2D font metrics, and all standard flexbox properties.

The engine is designed for the Love2D fixed-canvas model, not for scrolling web pages.
The viewport has a known size at all times, and every node's dimensions can be resolved
in a single top-down pass with one re-measure step for flex-distributed text nodes.
sections.api:
Public API:
  Layout.init(config)                - Initialize with { measure = MeasureModule }
  Layout.layout(node, x, y, w, h)   - Lay out entire tree from root
  Layout.layoutNode(node, px, py, pw, ph) - Lay out a single node recursively
  Layout.resolveUnit(value, parentSize)   - Resolve a value to pixels

Supported Unit Types:
  number      - Pixels (e.g., 200)
  "50%"       - Percentage of parent dimension
  "10vw"      - Percentage of viewport width
  "5vh"       - Percentage of viewport height

Supported Flexbox Properties:
  flexDirection:  'row' | 'column' (default: 'column')
  flexWrap:       'nowrap' | 'wrap' (default: 'nowrap')
  justifyContent: 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'space-between' | 'space-around' | 'space-evenly'
  alignItems:     'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'stretch' (default: 'stretch')
  alignSelf:      'auto' | 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'stretch'
  flexGrow:       number (default: 0)
  flexShrink:     number (default: 1, CSS spec default)
  flexBasis:      number | string | 'auto'
  gap:            number | string

examples.title: Layout Algorithm Overview
examples.code:
For each node, Layout.layoutNode performs these steps:

  1. Resolve own dimensions (width, height) from style + parent constraints
  2. Apply aspectRatio if set and one dimension is missing
  3. Apply flex-adjusted dimensions from parent distribution (_flexW, _stretchH)
  4. Resolve padding (all sides)
  5. Measure intrinsic text size if this is a Text node without explicit dimensions
  6. Apply min/max width/height clamping (re-measure text if width changed)
  7. Resolve margin (all sides)
  8. Compute inner dimensions (outer minus padding)
  9. Filter visible children (skip display: 'none')
  10. Split children into flex lines (single line if nowrap)
  11. For each flex line:
      a. Distribute flex-grow (positive free space) or flex-shrink (negative)
      b. Re-measure text nodes whose width changed from flex distribution
      c. Compute line cross-axis size
      d. Apply justifyContent offset and extra gap
      e. Position each child with alignItems/alignSelf
      f. Recurse into each child: Layout.layoutNode(child, ...)
  12. Auto-height: shrink to content if height was not explicit
  13. Track scroll content dimensions for scroll containers

examples.title: Text Measurement
examples.code:
Text measurement is the key difference from CSS flexbox. In a browser, the layout
engine has access to the full text shaping pipeline. In iLoveReact, text measurement
is done via Love2D's font:getWrap() and font:getWidth() APIs.

For a Text node without explicit width/height:
  1. Use parent's inner width as the wrap constraint
  2. Call measureText(text, fontSize, constraintWidth, fontFamily, lineHeight, letterSpacing, numberOfLines, fontWeight)
  3. Set node width = measured text width + padding
  4. Set node height = measured text height + padding

If flex-grow changes the node's width after initial measurement:
  5. Re-measure with the new width to get correct wrapped height

criticalRules: Nodes without explicit width default to their parent's width (not zero).
Nodes without explicit height auto-size to their content.
Scroll containers without explicit height default to 0 (they need explicit
height or flex-grow to be visible).
flexGrow only distributes positive free space. If the parent has no definite
size on the main axis, there is no free space to distribute.
The layout engine runs synchronously on every frame where the tree is dirty.

metadata.title: Target Painters
metadata.description: How each target platform converts computed layout into visible output

sections.overview:
After the layout engine computes positions and sizes for every node, the painter walks
the tree and issues platform-specific draw calls. Each target has its own painter
implementation. The painter reads the computed rect ({x, y, w, h}) and style properties
from each node, then translates them into the target's native rendering API.

The Love2D painter is the most full-featured, supporting backgrounds, borders, rounded
corners, gradients, shadows, text rendering with font metrics, image display with
object-fit modes, opacity propagation, stencil-based clipping, scissor rectangles,
scroll containers, transforms, and z-index ordering.

examples.title: Love2D Painter (painter.lua)
examples.code:
The Love2D painter uses love.graphics calls to render every node type:

View/Box nodes:
  - Box shadow: Multiple fading rectangles to simulate blur
  - Background gradient: Love2D mesh API with vertex colors
  - Background color: love.graphics.rectangle("fill", ...)
  - Border: love.graphics.rectangle("line", ...) or per-side lines
  - Per-corner border radius: Arc + polygon rendering
  - Outline: Drawn outside the border box
  - Overflow hidden: Stencil (rounded) or scissor (rectangular) clipping
  - Overflow scroll: Scissor clipping + love.graphics.translate for scroll offset
  - Scrollbar indicators: Small rectangles on right/bottom edges

Text nodes:
  - Font cache: Fonts loaded by (size, family, weight) tuple
  - Text alignment: love.graphics.printf with alignment parameter
  - Text truncation: Binary search for ellipsis cutoff point
  - numberOfLines: Wrap then truncate to line count
  - lineHeight override: Manual line-by-line rendering
  - letterSpacing: Character-by-character rendering (expensive)
  - Text shadow: Draw text twice with offset
  - Text decoration: Underline or strikethrough via love.graphics.line
  - Bold simulation: Draw text twice with 0.8px offset (faux bold)

Image nodes:
  - objectFit modes: fill, contain, cover, none
  - Border radius clipping via stencil
  - Image cache managed by images.lua module

Recursive tree walk:
  - Opacity propagates multiplicatively down the tree
  - Stencil depth tracks nested overflow:hidden contexts
  - zIndex reorders paint order within each parent's children
  - Transforms apply via love.graphics.push/pop matrix stack

examples.title: Web Painter (primitives.tsx)
examples.code:
The web "painter" is not a separate module -- it is built into the primitives. When RendererMode is 'web', Box renders as
, Text as , Image as . The styleToCSS() function converts the iLoveReact Style object to React CSSProperties: - flexDirection, justifyContent, alignItems mapped with flex-start/flex-end - Colors converted from [r,g,b,a] (0-1 range) to rgba() strings - Gradients converted to CSS linear-gradient - Transforms converted to CSS transform string - Transitions mapped to CSS transition property - boxShadow, textShadow composed from offset/blur/color - outline composed from width/color/offset The browser handles layout natively via its own flexbox engine.

examples.title: Terminal Painter
examples.code:
The terminal painter (@ilovereact/terminal) uses ANSI truecolor escape sequences.
The grid layout engine (@ilovereact/grid) computes character-cell positions.

Each cell is a single character with foreground and background colors:
  ESC[38;2;R;G;Bm    -- Set foreground (truecolor)
  ESC[48;2;R;G;Bm    -- Set background (truecolor)
  <character>         -- The cell content

The painter writes to a buffer, then flushes the entire screen to stdout.

metadata.title: Rendering Pipeline
metadata.description: End-to-end walkthrough of how React components become pixels on screen

sections.overview:
Every frame in iLoveReact follows a fixed rendering pipeline. Your React components
produce a virtual tree. The reconciler diffs that tree against the previous version and
emits mutation commands (create, update, remove, reorder). Those commands travel over a
transport layer to the target runtime. The layout engine computes positions and sizes
for every node. Finally, the painter draws the result to the screen.

This pipeline is the same for every target. Only the transport and painter differ.
The reconciler and layout engine are shared code.

examples.title: Pipeline Stages
examples.code:
Stage 1: React Reconciler (@ilovereact/native)
  Input:  Your JSX component tree
  Output: Mutation commands (JSON)
  What:   react-reconciler 0.29 diffs the virtual tree.
          Host elements are 'View', 'Text', 'Image'.
          Commands: createNode, updateProps, appendChild, removeChild,
                    insertBefore, commitTextUpdate.

Stage 2: Mutation Commands
  Format: Array of JSON objects, each with a `type` field:
          { type: "createNode", nodeType: "View", id: 1, props: { style: {...} } }
          { type: "updateProps", id: 1, props: { style: {...} } }
          { type: "appendChild", parentId: 0, childId: 1 }
          { type: "removeChild", parentId: 0, childId: 1 }

Stage 3: Transport Layer
  Love2D native: QuickJS FFI (bridge_quickjs.lua) -- JS runs inside QuickJS embedded in Love2D
  Love2D web:    Module.FS (bridge_fs.lua) -- commands written to shared Emscripten filesystem
  Grid targets:  WebSocket or stdio -- commands sent over network or pipes

Stage 4: Layout Engine (layout.lua)
  Input:  Retained node tree with style properties
  Output: Computed rect {x, y, w, h} for every node
  What:   Flexbox algorithm: resolves units (px, %, vw, vh),
          distributes flex-grow/shrink, measures text, applies
          justifyContent, alignItems, padding, margin, gap.

Stage 5: Target Painter
  Love2D:  love.graphics calls -- rectangles, text, images, stencils, scissors
  Web:     CSS flexbox in DOM -- styleToCSS conversion, div/span/img elements
  Terminal: ANSI truecolor escape sequences to stdout
  CC:      ComputerCraft term API with 16-color palette
  Neovim:  nvim floating window API
  HS:      hs.canvas pixel drawing
  Awesome: Cairo/Pango rendering

examples.title: Native Mode Frame Loop
examples.code:
On every love.update(dt):

  1. bridge:tick()                    -- Advance JS timers and microtasks
  2. bridge:callGlobal("_poll...")    -- JS processes pending input events
  3. bridge:tick()                    -- Event handlers may trigger state updates
  4. bridge:drainCommands()           -- Collect mutation commands from JS
  5. tree.applyCommands(commands)     -- Apply to retained Lua tree
  6. animate.tick(dt)                 -- Advance Lua-side transitions/animations
  7. if tree.isDirty() then
       layout.layout(root)           -- Recompute layout
     end

On every love.draw():
  8. painter.paint(root)              -- Walk tree, issue draw calls
  9. inspector.draw(root)             -- Debug overlay (if F12 enabled)
  10. errors.draw()                   -- Error overlay (if any errors)

metadata.title: React Reconciler
metadata.description: How @ilovereact/native uses react-reconciler to build the instance tree and emit mutation commands

sections.overview:
iLoveReact uses react-reconciler 0.29 (the same package React Native uses) to manage
the component tree. The reconciler calls into a host config that creates, updates, and
removes instances. In native mode, these instances are lightweight JavaScript objects
that map 1:1 to nodes in the Lua-side retained tree.

The reconciler does not draw anything. It produces mutation commands -- JSON objects
describing what changed. These commands are batched per frame and flushed to the
transport layer, which delivers them to the Lua runtime.

examples.title: How createLove2DApp Works
The Instance Model
examples.code:
Each reconciler instance is a plain object:

  {
    type: 'View',           // host element type
    id: 1,                  // unique numeric ID
    props: { style: {...} }, // current props (style, event handlers extracted)
    children: [],           // child instances
    parent: null,           // parent instance reference
  }

Event handlers (onClick, onKeyDown, etc.) are extracted from props and stored
in the handlerRegistry on the JS side. They never cross the bridge to Lua.
Only the handler's existence is communicated (so Lua knows to dispatch events
back to JS for that node).

seeAlso: pipeline.txt - Where the reconciler fits in the pipeline
transport.txt - How mutations reach the Lua runtime
10-advanced/event-handling.txt - How events flow back from Lua to JS

metadata.title: Source-of-Truth Architecture
metadata.description: Critical guide to file organization, editing rules, and the sync pipeline

sections.overview:
iLoveReact has two categories of files: globally distributed framework files and
project-specific application files. Editing the wrong copy is the number one source of
"it builds but does not work" bugs. Framework files have a single source of truth at the
monorepo root. They are copied into projects by the CLI. Application files are unique to
each project and are safe to edit directly.

Understanding this distinction and following the sync pipeline is critical for any work
that touches framework internals.
sections.api:
Source-of-Truth Locations:
  lua/*.lua                    -> Lua runtime (layout, painter, tree, events, etc.)
  packages/shared/src/         -> Core primitives, components, hooks, animation, types
  packages/native/src/         -> React reconciler, host config, bridge, entry points
  quickjs/libquickjs.so        -> QuickJS shared library

Copy Destinations (managed by tooling, NEVER edit directly):
  cli/runtime/lua/             <- make cli-setup copies lua/*.lua here
  cli/runtime/ilovereact/shared/ <- make cli-setup copies packages/shared/ here
  cli/runtime/ilovereact/native/ <- make cli-setup copies packages/native/ here
  cli/runtime/lib/             <- make cli-setup copies quickjs/libquickjs.so here
  <project>/lua/               <- ilovereact update copies here
  <project>/ilovereact/shared/ <- ilovereact update copies here
  <project>/ilovereact/native/ <- ilovereact update copies here
  <project>/lib/               <- ilovereact update copies here

Project-Specific Files (safe to edit directly):
  src/                         - Application code (App.tsx, stories, etc.)
  main.lua                     - Love2D entry point
  conf.lua                     - Love2D configuration
  package.json                 - Project dependencies
  packaging/                   - Build customizations

examples.title: The Sync Pipeline
examples.code:
When you edit a framework file (e.g., lua/layout.lua or packages/shared/src/types.ts):

  # Step 1: Edit the source-of-truth file at the monorepo root
  vim lua/layout.lua

  # Step 2: Propagate to CLI runtime
  make cli-setup

  # Step 3: For each project that needs the change
  cd examples/storybook
  ilovereact update          # Syncs lua/, lib/, ilovereact/ from CLI runtime
  ilovereact build dist:love # Rebuild with new code

examples.title: Adding a New Lua-Side Feature (Checklist)
examples.code:
1. Edit/create files in lua/ (the source of truth)
2. Edit/create files in packages/shared/src/ and packages/native/src/ as needed
3. Run: make cli-setup
4. For each example project that needs the feature:
   cd examples/<project>
   ilovereact update
   ilovereact build dist:love
5. For new projects: ilovereact init <name> gets everything automatically

criticalRules: ALWAYS edit source-of-truth files (lua/, packages/shared/, packages/native/).
NEVER edit copies (cli/runtime/, <project>/lua/, <project>/ilovereact/).
Those are disposable and will be overwritten by the next sync.
After editing any source-of-truth file, run the full sync pipeline:
make cli-setup, then ilovereact update in affected projects.
ilovereact update syncs lua/, lib/, and ilovereact/ from CLI runtime into
the project. It NEVER touches src/ (your application code is safe).
ilovereact init creates starter versions of src/, main.lua, conf.lua.
ilovereact update never touches those files.
ilovereact build dist:love has a fallback: if no local lua/ exists, it reads
from cli/runtime/lua/. But ilovereact dev and love . require local copies,
so always run ilovereact update for dev workflows.

metadata.title: Transport Layer
metadata.description: How mutation commands and events travel between React and target runtimes

sections.overview:
The transport layer is the communication channel between the React reconciler (running
in JavaScript) and the target runtime (Lua, terminal process, etc.). All transports
implement the IBridge interface, which provides subscribe, send, rpc, and setState
methods. React hooks consume IBridge via context and never know which transport is
active.

There are four transport implementations, each suited to a different deployment model.
The choice of transport is automatic based on the target and mode configuration.
sections.api:
IBridge Interface:
  send(type, payload?)           - Queue a command for the Lua side (batched)
  flush()                        - Write all queued commands to transport
  subscribe(type, fn)            - Subscribe to events from Lua; returns unsubscribe
  rpc<T>(method, args?, timeout?) - Call an RPC method on Lua, await response
  setState(key, value)           - Set a shared state key (convenience over send)
  isReady()                      - Whether the transport is initialized
  onReady(callback)              - Register callback for when transport becomes ready
  destroy()                      - Tear down transport resources

Transport Implementations:
  NativeBridge  (bridge_quickjs.lua) - QuickJS FFI for Love2D native builds
  WebBridge     (bridge_fs.lua)      - Module.FS for Love2D web (Emscripten) builds
  WebSocket     (ws)                 - For CC, Hammerspoon targets
  stdio         (process.stdin/out)  - For Neovim, AwesomeWM targets

examples.title: Native Mode (QuickJS FFI)
examples.code:
In native Love2D builds, JavaScript runs inside QuickJS, which is embedded in the
Love2D process via libquickjs.so (a shared library loaded with LuaJIT FFI).

Data flow:
  JS -> Lua: Mutation commands written to a shared buffer, drained each frame
             via bridge:drainCommands()
  Lua -> JS: Events pushed via bridge:pushEvent(), picked up by JS on next tick
             via globalThis._pollAndDispatchEvents()

The bridge also provides:
  bridge:eval(code, filename)        - Evaluate JS code in the QuickJS context
  bridge:callGlobal(name)            - Call a named global JS function
  bridge:callGlobalReturn(name)      - Call and return result as Lua value
  bridge:tick()                      - Advance JS timers and microtask queue

This is the fastest transport -- zero serialization overhead for most operations
because JS and Lua share the same process memory.

examples.title: Web Mode (Module.FS)
examples.code:
In browser builds (love.js / Emscripten), the Lua runtime and JavaScript run in
separate contexts. Communication happens via JSON files on the Emscripten shared
filesystem (Module.FS).

Data flow:
  JS -> Lua: Commands written to /__reconciler_in.json, polled by Lua each frame
  Lua -> JS: Events written to /__bridge_<namespace>_out.json, polled by JS

Both sides poll their respective inbox files on each frame tick and remove them
after reading.

examples.title: IBridge in React Hooks

seeAlso: reconciler.txt - What produces the mutation commands
10-advanced/lua-runtime.txt - The Lua side that receives them

metadata.title: ilovereact build
metadata.description: Bundle JS for development or produce self-contained distribution packages.

sections.overview:
The `ilovereact build` command bundles JavaScript and optionally produces self-contained
distribution packages. Without a target, it runs the lint gate and bundles JS for the
`love .` dev workflow. With a target (dist:love or dist:terminal), it produces a standalone
executable.

Every build automatically runs `ilovereact update` first (unless --no-update) and passes
through the lint gate -- builds fail on lint errors. This ensures that distribution packages
always contain up-to-date framework files and pass layout validation.
sections.api:
Usage:
  ilovereact build [target] [flags]

Targets:
  (none)          Lint gate + bundle JS for dev (outputs bundle.js for `love .` workflow)
  dist:love       Self-extracting Linux binary with bundled glibc, Love2D, and QuickJS
  dist:terminal   Single-file Node.js executable with shebang

Flags:
  --no-update     Skip the automatic `ilovereact update` step
  --debug         Enable the visual inspector (F12) in dist:love builds
                  (inspector is disabled by default in dist builds)

Build steps for each target:

  No target (dev bundle):
    1. ilovereact update (sync runtime files)
    2. Lint gate (fail on errors)
    3. esbuild --format=iife --global-name=ReactLove
    4. Output: bundle.js

  dist:love:
    1. ilovereact update
    2. Bundle JS (IIFE for QuickJS)
    3. Stage .love archive (main.lua, conf.lua, lua/, bundle.js)
    4. Create .love zip archive
    5. Bundle Love2D binary + all shared libraries (including glibc)
    6. Create launcher script
    7. Pack into single self-extracting binary
    8. Output: dist/<project-name>
    Entry: src/main-love.tsx or src/native-main.tsx or src/main.tsx (first found)

  dist:terminal:
    1. Bundle JS (CJS for Node.js, --platform=node, --external:ws)
    2. Prepend shebang (#!/usr/bin/env node)
    3. Output: dist/<project-name>-terminal
    Entry: src/main-terminal.tsx

examples.title: Dev bundle
examples.code:
ilovereact build
love .

examples.title: Self-extracting Love2D binary
examples.code:
ilovereact build dist:love
./dist/my-app

examples.title: Debug build with inspector
examples.code: ilovereact build dist:love --debug

examples.title: Terminal executable
examples.code:
ilovereact build dist:terminal
./dist/my-app-terminal

examples.title: Skip runtime update
examples.code: ilovereact build --no-update

criticalRules: Build always runs the lint gate -- fix all lint errors before building
Build always runs `ilovereact update` unless --no-update is passed
The inspector (F12) is automatically disabled in dist:love builds (pass --debug to keep it)
dist:love only works on x86_64 Linux (bundles host system's glibc and shared libraries)
dist:love requires Love2D installed on the build machine
Never run raw esbuild manually -- the CLI encodes correct flags for each target
seeAlso: dev.txt -- Watch mode for iterative development

metadata.title: ilovereact dev
metadata.description: Start esbuild in watch mode for live Love2D development.

sections.overview:
The `ilovereact dev` command starts esbuild in watch mode, continuously rebuilding the
JavaScript bundle whenever source files change. It uses the correct esbuild flags for the
Love2D target (IIFE format, ReactLove global name, ES2020 target, automatic JSX).

Run `love .` in a separate terminal to see your app. Love2D reads the bundle.js file on
each frame update, so changes appear in real time without restarting Love2D.
sections.api:
Usage:
  ilovereact dev

Entry point:
  src/main.tsx (required -- the command exits with an error if this file does not exist)

Output:
  bundle.js in the project root

esbuild flags used:
  --bundle
  --format=iife
  --global-name=ReactLove
  --target=es2020
  --jsx=automatic
  --outfile=bundle.js
  --watch

examples.title: Standard development workflow
examples.code:
# Terminal 1:
cd my-project
ilovereact dev

# Terminal 2:
cd my-project
love .

criticalRules: The project must have a src/main.tsx entry point
Do NOT run raw esbuild --watch manually -- the CLI encodes the correct flags
The dev command requires local lua/ and lib/ directories (run `ilovereact update` first if missing)
Love2D must be running in a separate terminal -- the dev command only watches and bundles JS
Ctrl+C exits the watcher
seeAlso: lint.txt -- Run the linter separately during development
init.txt -- Creating new projects with the correct structure

metadata.title: CLI Reference
metadata.description: Overview of the ilovereact CLI tool and its commands.

sections.overview:
The ilovereact CLI is the primary tool for creating, developing, building, and testing
iLoveReact projects. It encodes correct esbuild flags, enforces lint gates before builds,
handles runtime file placement, and produces distribution packages. You should always use
the CLI instead of running raw esbuild commands directly -- manual esbuild will use wrong
flags, skip linting, and produce broken builds.

The CLI manages the distinction between framework files (lua/, lib/, ilovereact/) and
project-specific files (src/, main.lua, conf.lua). Framework files are synced from the CLI
runtime; project files are yours and never touched by CLI commands.
sections.api:
Available commands:

  ilovereact init <name>
    Create a new iLoveReact project.
    See: init.txt

  ilovereact dev
    Start esbuild in watch mode for live development.
    See: dev.txt

  ilovereact build [target] [flags]
    Bundle JS or produce distribution packages.
    Targets: (none), dist:love, dist:terminal
    Flags: --no-update, --debug
    See: build.txt

  ilovereact update
    Sync framework runtime files into the current project.
    See: update.txt

  ilovereact lint
    Run the static layout linter on src/ files.
    See: lint.txt

  ilovereact screenshot [--output path]
    Capture a headless screenshot of the current app.
    See: screenshot.txt

examples.title: Typical new project workflow
examples.code:
ilovereact init my-app
cd my-app
ilovereact dev
# In another terminal:
love .

examples.title: Build and verify workflow
examples.code:
ilovereact lint
ilovereact screenshot --output /tmp/preview.png
ilovereact build dist:love

examples.title: After framework changes
examples.code:
# In monorepo root:
make cli-setup
# In project directory:
cd examples/storybook
ilovereact update
ilovereact build

criticalRules: Always use the CLI instead of running esbuild directly
Run `ilovereact lint` after every component change
Run `ilovereact screenshot` to visually verify layouts
After editing framework source-of-truth files, run `make cli-setup` then `ilovereact update`
Never edit cli/runtime/ or project lua/ilovereact/ directly -- those are disposable copies

metadata.title: ilovereact init
metadata.description: Create a new iLoveReact project with scaffolded structure and dependencies.

sections.overview:
The `ilovereact init` command creates a new iLoveReact project directory with the complete
scaffolding needed to start development. It copies the project template, Lua runtime files,
native libraries, and framework source packages from the CLI runtime directory, writes a
package.json, and runs npm install.

After init completes, you can immediately start development with `ilovereact dev` and
`love .` in a second terminal.
sections.api:
Usage:
  ilovereact init <name>

Arguments:
  name    The project name. Creates a directory with this name in the current working directory.

What it creates:
  <name>/
    src/
      App.tsx          Starter application component
      main.tsx         Entry point (renders App into the reconciler)
    lua/               Lua runtime files (layout.lua, painter.lua, bridge_quickjs.lua, etc.)
    lib/
      libquickjs.so    QuickJS shared library for FFI bridge
    ilovereact/
      shared/          @ilovereact/core package source (primitives, hooks, animation)
      native/          @ilovereact/native package source (reconciler host config)
    main.lua           Love2D entry point
    conf.lua           Love2D configuration (window size, title)
    package.json       Project dependencies and scripts

Dependencies installed:
  react ^18.3.0
  react-reconciler ^0.29.0
  esbuild ^0.24.0 (dev)
  @types/react ^18.3.0 (dev)
  typescript ^5.5.0 (dev)

examples.title: Create a new project
examples.code:
ilovereact init my-game
cd my-game
ilovereact dev

examples.title: Create and immediately build
examples.code:
ilovereact init dashboard
cd dashboard
ilovereact build dist:love

criticalRules: The project name becomes the directory name -- it must not already exist
The CLI runtime directory must be populated first (run `make cli-setup` in the monorepo root)
If the runtime is missing, init will warn but still create the project structure
Never manually create project directories with mkdir + cp -- always use init
Project files (src/, main.lua, conf.lua) are yours to edit. Framework files (lua/, lib/, ilovereact/) are managed by the CLI and will be overwritten by `ilovereact update`
seeAlso: update.txt -- Sync framework files after changes

metadata.title: ilovereact lint
metadata.description: Static layout linter that catches common iLoveReact mistakes at build time.

sections.overview:
The `ilovereact lint` command runs a static layout linter on all .tsx files in the project's
src/ directory. It uses TypeScript's AST parser (ts.createSourceFile) to analyze JSX elements
and their style props without type checking. The linter catches layout mistakes that would
produce invisible, overlapping, or incorrectly sized elements at runtime.

The linter is also run automatically as a lint gate during `ilovereact build` -- builds fail
when error-level rules are violated. You should run the linter after every component change
to catch issues early.
sections.api:
Usage:
  ilovereact lint

Runs on:
  All .tsx files under src/ (recursively, skipping node_modules, dist, .git, build, out)

Error rules (block builds):

  no-text-without-fontsize
    Every <Text> element must have fontSize in its style. Without it, text measurement
    fails and layout is incorrect.

  no-block-char-in-text
    The block character (U+2588) in <Text> renders as a font glyph with gaps, not a filled
    pixel. Use Box with backgroundColor instead.

  no-mixed-text-children
    Mixed literal text and JSX expressions in <Text> (e.g., Score: {score}) creates multiple
    __TEXT__ nodes that overlap. Use a template literal: {`Score: ${score}`}.

  no-row-justify-without-width
    A row container (flexDirection: 'row') with justifyContent but no explicit width. Box
    nodes have no intrinsic width, so justifyContent has nothing to distribute.
    Exception: justifyContent: 'start' does not trigger this rule.

  no-flexgrow-root
    Root container (top-level JSX with no parent) uses flexGrow without width/height. The
    root has no parent to grow into. Use width: '100%', height: '100%' instead.

  no-invalid-style-props
    Style object contains properties not recognized by iLoveReact's style system. Only
    checked on iLoveReact primitives (Box, Text, Image, etc.), not on HTML elements.

  no-link-without-to
    <Link> component is missing the "to" prop for navigation target.

  no-usecrud-without-schema
    useCRUD() hook called without a schema argument (requires at least 2 arguments).

Warning rules (advisory):

  no-uncontexted-flexgrow
    flexGrow used where siblings lack explicit main-axis sizing. Layout depends on content
    measurement, which is unreliable.

  no-deep-flex-nesting
    Flex container nested 4+ levels deep without explicit width and height. May produce
    unexpected layout.

  no-flexrow-flexcolumn
    Using <FlexRow> or <FlexColumn> instead of <Box> with flexDirection. Prefer Box to keep
    the layout tree transparent.

  no-implicit-container-sizing
    Container with more than 5 direct children but no explicit width/height.

  no-routes-without-fallback
    <Routes> without a <Route path="*"> catch-all for 404 handling.

Escape hatch:
  // ilr-ignore-next-line
  Place this comment on the line immediately before the JSX element to suppress all rules
  for that element.

Exit code:
  0 if no errors (warnings are OK)
  1 if any error-level rules are violated

examples.title: Run the linter
examples.code:
cd my-project
ilovereact lint

examples.title: Suppress a lint rule
Typical lint output
examples.code:
src/App.tsx
    12:5  error  Text element missing fontSize in style  [no-text-without-fontsize]
    28:3  error  Row with justifyContent but no width     [no-row-justify-without-width]
    45:7  warn   flexGrow used but sibling lacks width    [no-uncontexted-flexgrow]

  2 errors, 1 warning in 3 files

criticalRules: Run the linter after EVERY component change
Error-level rules block builds -- they must be fixed or explicitly suppressed
The escape hatch (// ilr-ignore-next-line) should be used sparingly
Style passed via variables (style={myStyle}) cannot be analyzed -- the linter skips those
Style objects with spread operators ({...baseStyle, fontSize: 14}) are partially analyzed
Only iLoveReact primitives are linted (Box, Text, Image, etc.) -- HTML elements are skipped
seeAlso: build.txt -- Build command includes lint gate
../04-layout-system/critical-rules.txt -- Detailed explanations of each critical rule

metadata.title: ilovereact screenshot
metadata.description: Capture a headless screenshot of the current app state for visual layout verification.

sections.overview:
The `ilovereact screenshot` command runs the full lint + build pipeline, then launches
Love2D in headless screenshot mode to capture the current app state as a PNG image. This is
the primary tool for visual verification of layouts without manually inspecting a running
Love2D window.

The command automatically detects xvfb-run for truly headless operation on servers or CI
environments. If xvfb-run is not available, it launches Love2D normally (requires a display).
sections.api:
Usage:
  ilovereact screenshot [--output path]

Options:
  --output, -o    Path for the output PNG file.
                  Default: screenshot.png in the project root.

Steps performed:
  1. Lint gate (fails on errors, same as `ilovereact lint`)
  2. Bundle JS (esbuild with IIFE format for Love2D)
  3. Launch Love2D with ILOVEREACT_SCREENSHOT=1 environment variable
  4. Love2D renders one frame and saves to the specified output path
  5. Love2D exits automatically after saving

Environment variables set:
  ILOVEREACT_SCREENSHOT=1
  ILOVEREACT_SCREENSHOT_OUTPUT=<absolute output path>

Timeout:
  15 seconds. If Love2D does not produce a screenshot within this window, the command
  fails with a timeout error.

examples.title: Default screenshot
examples.code:
ilovereact screenshot
# Output: screenshot.png in project root

examples.title: Custom output path
examples.code: ilovereact screenshot --output /tmp/preview.png

examples.title: CI verification workflow
examples.code:
ilovereact lint
ilovereact screenshot --output /tmp/layout-check.png
# Inspect /tmp/layout-check.png or diff against a reference image

criticalRules: The lint gate runs before screenshot capture -- fix lint errors first
Love2D must be installed and available in PATH
For headless environments, install xvfb-run (apt install xvfb on Debian/Ubuntu)
The screenshot reflects the initial render state (no user interaction)
15-second timeout -- if your app hangs during initialization, the command will fail
The entry point must be src/main.tsx
seeAlso: lint.txt -- Lint gate that runs before screenshot

metadata.title: ilovereact update
metadata.description: Sync framework runtime files from the CLI into the current project.

sections.overview:
The `ilovereact update` command synchronizes the framework runtime files (lua/, lib/, and
ilovereact/) from the CLI runtime directory into the current project. It replaces these
directories entirely, bringing the project up to date with the latest framework code.

This command never touches project-specific files (src/, main.lua, conf.lua, package.json).
It is the second step in the framework update pipeline: first `make cli-setup` copies source-of-truth
files into the CLI runtime, then `ilovereact update` copies from the CLI runtime into each project.
sections.api:
Usage:
  ilovereact update

Prerequisite:
  Must be run from inside an iLoveReact project directory (detected by presence of main.lua
  or src/ directory).

What it syncs:
  cli/runtime/lua/         ->  <project>/lua/
  cli/runtime/lib/         ->  <project>/lib/
  cli/runtime/ilovereact/  ->  <project>/ilovereact/

What it does NOT touch:
  src/              Project source code
  main.lua          Love2D entry point
  conf.lua          Love2D configuration
  package.json      Project dependencies
  packaging/        Build customizations

The update is destructive for the synced directories -- existing lua/, lib/, and ilovereact/
directories are deleted and replaced entirely.

examples.title: After editing framework source files
examples.code:
# Edit source-of-truth files:
#   lua/layout.lua
#   packages/shared/src/primitives.tsx

# Propagate to CLI runtime:
make cli-setup

# Sync into project:
cd examples/storybook
ilovereact update

# Rebuild:
ilovereact build

examples.title: Hydrate an existing project
examples.code:
cd my-project
ilovereact update

criticalRules: Always run `make cli-setup` in the monorepo root BEFORE running `ilovereact update`
The CLI runtime must be populated (`cli/runtime/lua/` and `cli/runtime/ilovereact/` must exist)
Never edit lua/, lib/, or ilovereact/ in a project directly -- those are disposable copies managed by update
The update deletes and replaces the target directories entirely -- any local modifications are lost
Must be run from inside an iLoveReact project directory
seeAlso: init.txt -- Initial project creation (includes the first sync)
build.txt -- Build command runs update automatically

metadata.title: Critical Layout Rules
metadata.description: The most important layout rules in iLoveReact. Violating these causes the most common bugs.

sections.overview:
These are the rules that cause the most bugs in iLoveReact development. The static linter
(ilovereact lint) enforces most of them at build time, blocking builds that violate error-level
rules. Understanding these rules is essential for productive development. Each rule exists
because of a concrete limitation of the layout engine or rendering pipeline.

The linter runs automatically during `ilovereact build` (lint gate). You should also run
`ilovereact lint` after every component change to catch issues early. Rules can be bypassed
on a per-line basis with the `// ilr-ignore-next-line` comment, but this should be rare.
sections.api:
Linter escape hatch:

  // ilr-ignore-next-line
  <Text style={{ color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Intentionally no fontSize</Text>

This suppresses all linter rules for the next line. Use sparingly.

examples.title: WRONG -- root uses flexGrow (linter error: no-flexgrow-root)
RIGHT -- root uses explicit dimensions
WRONG -- Text without fontSize (linter error: no-text-without-fontsize)
examples.code: <Text style={{ color: '#cdd6f4' }}>This text cannot be measured</Text>

examples.title: WRONG -- mixed text children (linter error: no-mixed-text-children)
RIGHT -- template literal instead of mixed children
examples.code:
<Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>
  {`Score: ${score}`}
</Text>

examples.title: WRONG -- row justifyContent without width (linter error: no-row-justify-without-width)
examples.code:
<Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row', justifyContent: 'center' }}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Not centered</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: RIGHT -- row justifyContent with explicit width
examples.code:
<Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row', width: '100%', justifyContent: 'center' }}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Centered</Text>
</Box>

criticalRules: 1. Root containers MUST have width: '100%', height: '100%' -- NOT flexGrow: 1
Why: flexGrow on the root has no parent container to grow into. The root element IS the
outermost container. Without explicit dimensions, it has zero size.
Linter: no-flexgrow-root (error)
2. Every Text element MUST have explicit fontSize
Why: The layout engine measures text using the font at the specified size. Without fontSize,
text measurement fails and the layout is incorrect. There is no default fontSize.
Linter: no-text-without-fontsize (error)
3. No flexGrow without sibling sizing context
Why: flexGrow distributes remaining space among children. If no sibling has an explicit
main-axis size, the "remaining space" is undefined and layout becomes content-dependent
(unreliable). At least one sibling needs a fixed size to anchor the flex calculation.
Linter: no-uncontexted-flexgrow (warning)
4. Row Boxes with justifyContent MUST have explicit width
Why: Box nodes have no intrinsic width (only Text nodes do). A row Box without width has
zero available space, so justifyContent has nothing to distribute. Always add width: '100%'
or a fixed width to row Boxes that use justifyContent (except 'start', which is the default).
Linter: no-row-justify-without-width (error)
5. Pre-compute grid dimensions
Why: Do not rely on child content to infer container size. The layout engine works top-down
from parent to child. If a parent has no explicit size, its children's flex properties have
no context to compute against.
6. Keep flex trees shallow
Why: Deep nesting of flex containers without explicit dimensions causes cascading layout
ambiguity. Each level of nesting without explicit sizing adds uncertainty. Prefer explicit
dimensions or flat layouts.
Linter: no-deep-flex-nesting (warning, triggers at depth 4+)
7. Fill the viewport
Why: Love2D renders to a fixed canvas with a known resolution (set in conf.lua). Unlike
a web browser, there is no scrolling viewport. Your app must fill the canvas or unused
areas will show the background color.
8. No mixed text and expressions in Text -- use template literals
Why: <Text>Score: {score}</Text> creates two separate __TEXT__ nodes ("Score: " and the
value of score). The layout engine lays these out as separate flex items at y=0, causing
them to overlap. Using {`Score: ${score}`} produces a single __TEXT__ node.
Linter: no-mixed-text-children (error)
9. Use block char as grid blueprint, never in Text
Why: The block character (U+2588) renders as a font glyph in Text, not a filled pixel.
It has gaps between characters and does not produce solid fills. Convert block-char art
into a boolean grid and render each cell as a Box with backgroundColor.
Linter: no-block-char-in-text (error)
seeAlso: sizing.txt -- Width, height, and sizing rules

metadata.title: Flexbox Layout Model
metadata.description: How iLoveReact uses Flexbox for all layout, with column as the default direction.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact uses Flexbox for all layout, mirroring React Native's approach. Every Box is
implicitly a flex container -- there is no need to set display: 'flex' (it is the default).
The critical difference from CSS is that flexDirection defaults to 'column', not 'row'.
This means children stack vertically unless you explicitly set flexDirection: 'row'.

The layout engine on the Lua side resolves flex properties into absolute positions and
sizes. It supports the standard flex properties: main axis distribution (justifyContent),
cross axis alignment (alignItems, alignSelf), flex sizing (flexGrow, flexShrink, flexBasis),
wrapping (flexWrap), and gap spacing. All values use the same names as CSS Flexbox except
that 'start' and 'end' are used instead of 'flex-start' and 'flex-end'.
sections.api:
Flexbox style properties (all set via the `style` prop on Box):

  flexDirection: 'row' | 'column'
    Default: 'column'
    Sets the main axis. 'column' stacks children vertically, 'row' stacks horizontally.

  justifyContent: 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'space-between' | 'space-around' | 'space-evenly'
    Default: 'start'
    Distributes children along the main axis.
    IMPORTANT: For row containers, justifyContent only works when the Box has an explicit
    width. Box nodes have no intrinsic width, so without one the engine cannot distribute
    space. The linter enforces this.

  alignItems: 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'stretch'
    Default: 'stretch'
    Aligns children along the cross axis.

  alignSelf: 'auto' | 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'stretch'
    Default: 'auto' (inherits parent's alignItems)
    Overrides the parent's alignItems for a specific child.

  flexGrow: number
    Default: 0
    How much of the remaining space this child should consume.
    Must have sibling sizing context to work predictably -- the linter warns when all
    siblings grow without explicit main-axis dimensions.

  flexShrink: number
    Default: 1
    How much this child should shrink when the container is too small.

  flexBasis: number | string | 'auto'
    Default: 'auto'
    The initial size of the child before flexGrow/flexShrink are applied.

  flexWrap: 'nowrap' | 'wrap'
    Default: 'nowrap'
    Whether children wrap to the next line when they exceed the container size.

  gap: number | string
    Spacing between children (applied uniformly on the main axis).

  display: 'flex' | 'none'
    Default: 'flex'
    Set to 'none' to hide an element entirely (does not occupy space).

examples.title: Vertical stack (default)
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%' }}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 20, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>First</Text>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 20, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Second</Text>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 20, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Third</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Horizontal row with space-between
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  flexDirection: 'row',
  width: '100%',
  justifyContent: 'space-between',
  padding: 12,
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Left</Text>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Center</Text>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Right</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Centered content
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: '100%',
  height: '100%',
  justifyContent: 'center',
  alignItems: 'center',
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 32, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Centered</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: flexGrow with sibling sizing
examples.code:
<Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row', width: '100%', height: 50 }}>
  <Box style={{ width: 100, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ flexGrow: 1, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 100, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
</Box>

examples.title: Wrapping row
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  flexDirection: 'row',
  flexWrap: 'wrap',
  width: 300,
  gap: 8,
}}>
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#f9e2af' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#cba6f7' }} />
</Box>

criticalRules: flexDirection defaults to 'column', not 'row' -- this is the opposite of CSS default
justifyContent on a row Box REQUIRES explicit width -- Box nodes have no intrinsic width
flexGrow without sibling sizing context produces unreliable layout
All siblings using flexGrow without any explicit main-axis size causes content-dependent layout
Use 'start'/'end', not 'flex-start'/'flex-end' -- the framework handles the conversion
Prefer Box with flexDirection: 'row' over FlexRow component (linter warns about FlexRow)
flexGrow on a root container is useless -- there is no parent to grow into

metadata.title: Layout System
metadata.description: Overview of the iLoveReact layout system, based on Flexbox with fixed-canvas semantics.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact uses a Flexbox layout model for all targets, similar to React Native. Every Box
is a flex container by default, with flexDirection defaulting to 'column'. There are no
block, inline, or grid display modes -- everything is flex. The layout engine runs on the
Lua side (layout.lua), computing absolute positions and sizes from the style tree that
React produces.

Because Love2D renders to a fixed canvas (not a scrolling web page), the layout system
demands explicit sizing at the root level and encourages explicit dimensions throughout.
The static linter (ilovereact lint) enforces critical layout rules at build time, catching
the most common mistakes before they reach the renderer. Understanding these rules is
essential for productive development with iLoveReact.
sections.api:
The layout system is configured entirely through the `style` prop on Box, Text, and Image
primitives. All style properties are defined in the Style interface (packages/shared/src/types.ts).

Layout-related style categories:
  - Flexbox: flexDirection, justifyContent, alignItems, alignSelf, flexGrow, flexShrink, flexBasis, flexWrap, gap
  - Sizing: width, height, minWidth, minHeight, maxWidth, maxHeight, aspectRatio
  - Spacing: padding, paddingLeft/Right/Top/Bottom, margin, marginLeft/Right/Top/Bottom, gap
  - Visual: backgroundColor, borderRadius, borderWidth, borderColor, opacity, overflow, zIndex, shadows, gradients
  - Text: color, fontSize, fontFamily, fontWeight, textAlign, textOverflow, lineHeight, letterSpacing
  - Transforms: transform object with translateX/Y, rotate, scaleX/Y, skewX/Y, originX/Y

examples.title: Full-viewport root container
Row layout with centered content
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  flexDirection: 'row',
  width: '100%',
  justifyContent: 'space-between',
  alignItems: 'center',
  padding: 16,
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 18, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Left</Text>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 18, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Right</Text>
</Box>

criticalRules: Root containers MUST have width: '100%', height: '100%' -- NOT flexGrow: 1
Every Text MUST have explicit fontSize -- the linter enforces this
Row Boxes with justifyContent MUST have explicit width
No flexGrow without sibling sizing context
Keep flex trees shallow -- prefer explicit dimensions over deep nesting
Fill the viewport -- Love2D is a fixed canvas, not a scrolling page
See critical-rules.txt for the complete list
seeAlso: critical-rules.txt -- All critical layout rules with explanations

metadata.title: Width, Height, and Min/Max Sizing
metadata.description: Sizing properties for controlling element dimensions in iLoveReact.

sections.overview:
Every element in iLoveReact has explicit sizing control through width, height, and their
min/max variants. Values can be numbers (interpreted as pixels on Love2D/web, or character
cells on grid targets) or percentage strings like '100%' or '50%'. Unlike the web, Box
elements in iLoveReact have no intrinsic width -- if you do not specify a width, it is
effectively zero unless flexGrow or alignItems: 'stretch' provides one.

Root containers must always use width: '100%', height: '100%' to fill the viewport. This
is the most common mistake in iLoveReact development and is enforced by the linter. Using
flexGrow: 1 on the root does not work because there is no parent container to grow into.
sections.api:
Sizing style properties:

  width: number | string
    Width in pixels (number) or percentage of parent ('50%', '100%').
    Box nodes have zero intrinsic width. Text nodes have intrinsic width from font measurement.

  height: number | string
    Height in pixels (number) or percentage of parent.
    Box nodes have zero intrinsic height. Text nodes have intrinsic height from fontSize.

  minWidth: number | string
    Minimum width constraint. The element will not shrink below this value.

  minHeight: number | string
    Minimum height constraint.

  maxWidth: number | string
    Maximum width constraint. The element will not grow beyond this value.

  maxHeight: number | string
    Maximum height constraint.

  aspectRatio: number
    Maintains a width-to-height ratio. For example, aspectRatio: 16/9 with width: 320
    produces height: 180. If only one dimension is set, the other is computed from the ratio.

examples.title: Root container filling viewport
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e' }}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 20, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Full viewport</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Fixed-size box
examples.code: <Box style={{ width: 200, height: 100, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa', borderRadius: 8 }} />

examples.title: Percentage-based sizing
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%' }}>
  <Box style={{ width: '50%', height: '30%', backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
</Box>

examples.title: Min/max constraints
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: '80%',
  minWidth: 200,
  maxWidth: 600,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f9e2af',
}} />

examples.title: Aspect ratio
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 320,
  aspectRatio: 16 / 9,
  backgroundColor: '#cba6f7',
  borderRadius: 8,
}} />

criticalRules: Root containers MUST use width: '100%', height: '100%' -- NOT flexGrow: 1
Box nodes have zero intrinsic width and height -- always specify dimensions or use flex sizing
Text nodes have intrinsic dimensions based on fontSize and content -- but you still MUST set fontSize
Pre-compute grid dimensions rather than relying on child content to infer container size
Percentage values are relative to the parent's computed dimension, not the viewport (unless the parent is the root)
seeAlso: spacing.txt -- Padding and margin affect effective size
critical-rules.txt -- Root sizing and other critical rules

metadata.title: Padding, Margin, and Gap
metadata.description: Spacing properties for controlling element padding, margin, and flex gap.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact supports padding (inner spacing), margin (outer spacing), and gap (spacing
between flex children). These work the same way as in CSS Flexbox: padding creates space
inside the element's border, margin creates space outside, and gap creates uniform spacing
between sibling children in a flex container.

All spacing values accept numbers (pixels on Love2D/web, character cells on grid targets)
or percentage strings. Shorthand properties (padding, margin) apply to all four sides, and
per-side properties (paddingLeft, marginTop, etc.) override the shorthand for specific sides.
sections.api:
Padding properties:

  padding: number | string
    Applies uniform padding to all four sides.

  paddingLeft: number | string
  paddingRight: number | string
  paddingTop: number | string
  paddingBottom: number | string
    Per-side padding. Overrides the shorthand `padding` for the specified side.

Margin properties:

  margin: number | string
    Applies uniform margin to all four sides.

  marginLeft: number | string
  marginRight: number | string
  marginTop: number | string
  marginBottom: number | string
    Per-side margin. Overrides the shorthand `margin` for the specified side.

Gap property:

  gap: number | string
    Spacing between children along the main axis of a flex container.
    Applied between each pair of adjacent children.

examples.title: Uniform padding
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: '100%',
  height: '100%',
  padding: 24,
  backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e',
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>
    {`24px of space on all sides`}
  </Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Per-side padding
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 300,
  height: 100,
  paddingLeft: 20,
  paddingRight: 20,
  paddingTop: 8,
  paddingBottom: 8,
  backgroundColor: '#313244',
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Asymmetric padding</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Margin for spacing between siblings
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', padding: 16 }}>
  <Box style={{ height: 50, marginBottom: 12, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, marginBottom: 12, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
</Box>

examples.title: Gap for uniform child spacing
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', padding: 16, gap: 12 }}>
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
</Box>

examples.title: Row with gap
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  flexDirection: 'row',
  width: '100%',
  gap: 8,
  padding: 16,
}}>
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
</Box>

criticalRules: Padding reduces the available content area inside an element
Margin does not collapse in Flexbox layout (unlike CSS block layout)
Gap is applied between children only, not before the first or after the last child
Per-side properties (paddingLeft, marginTop, etc.) override the shorthand for that side
Percentage spacing values are relative to the parent container's width (matching CSS behavior)
seeAlso: flexbox.txt -- Flexbox layout and gap usage
sizing.txt -- How sizing interacts with padding
visual.txt -- Border width also affects content area

metadata.title: Text-Specific Style Properties
metadata.description: Styling properties for the Text primitive, including font, color, alignment, and decoration.

sections.overview:
The Text primitive has its own set of style properties for controlling typography. The most
important rule in iLoveReact is that every Text element MUST have an explicit fontSize in
its style. This is not optional -- the layout engine needs fontSize to measure text and
compute layout, and the linter will block builds that violate this rule.

Text styling covers font properties (size, family, weight), text layout (alignment,
overflow, line height, letter spacing), text decoration (underline, strikethrough), and
text shadow. Colors use the same Color type as visual styling (CSS strings or Love2D-style
arrays).
sections.api:
Text style properties:

  color: Color
    Text color. Accepts CSS strings ("#cdd6f4") or Love2D arrays ([0.8, 0.84, 0.96]).

  fontSize: number (REQUIRED)
    Font size in pixels (Love2D/web) or character scale (grid targets).
    This property is MANDATORY on every Text element. The linter enforces this with the
    'no-text-without-fontsize' rule.

  fontFamily: string
    Font family name. On Love2D, this must be a font file available in the project.
    On web, it maps to CSS font-family.

  fontWeight: 'normal' | 'bold' | number
    Font weight. 'normal' is typically 400, 'bold' is 700. Numeric values (100-900)
    are supported on web and Love2D (if the font file supports weight variants).

  textAlign: 'left' | 'center' | 'right'
    Horizontal text alignment within the Text element's bounds.
    Default: 'left'

  textOverflow: 'clip' | 'ellipsis'
    How to handle text that overflows its container.
    'clip': text is cut off at the boundary.
    'ellipsis': text is truncated with "..." at the boundary.

  textDecorationLine: 'none' | 'underline' | 'line-through'
    Text decoration. 'underline' draws a line below the text, 'line-through' draws
    a line through the middle.

  lineHeight: number
    Line height in pixels. Controls the vertical spacing between lines of text.
    On web, this is converted to CSS line-height with 'px' units.

  letterSpacing: number
    Additional horizontal space between characters, in pixels.

  textShadowColor: Color
    Color of the text shadow. If not set, no text shadow is rendered.

  textShadowOffsetX: number
    Horizontal offset of the text shadow.

  textShadowOffsetY: number
    Vertical offset of the text shadow.

examples.title: Basic text with required fontSize
examples.code: <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Hello, world</Text>

examples.title: Styled heading
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 32,
  fontWeight: 'bold',
  color: '#cba6f7',
  textAlign: 'center',
  letterSpacing: 2,
}}>
  Dashboard
</Text>

examples.title: Text with decoration
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 14,
  color: '#a6adc8',
  textDecorationLine: 'underline',
}}>
  Click here for details
</Text>

examples.title: Multiline text with lineHeight
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 14,
  color: '#cdd6f4',
  lineHeight: 22,
}}>
  {`This is a longer paragraph of text that demonstrates line height control. Each line has 22 pixels of vertical space.`}
</Text>

examples.title: Text overflow with ellipsis
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: 200 }}>
  <Text style={{
    fontSize: 14,
    color: '#cdd6f4',
    textOverflow: 'ellipsis',
  }}>
    {`This is a very long string that will be truncated with an ellipsis`}
  </Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Text shadow
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 24,
  color: '#cdd6f4',
  textShadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
  textShadowOffsetX: 2,
  textShadowOffsetY: 2,
}}>
  Shadow Text
</Text>

criticalRules: Every Text element MUST have explicit fontSize -- builds will fail without it (linter rule: no-text-without-fontsize)
Do NOT mix literal text and JSX expressions in Text children -- use template literals instead (linter rule: no-mixed-text-children)
WRONG: <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>Score: {score}</Text>
RIGHT: <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>{`Score: ${score}`}</Text>
Do NOT use the block character (U+2588) in Text elements -- it renders as a font glyph, not a filled pixel (linter rule: no-block-char-in-text)
Text nodes have intrinsic dimensions from font measurement -- they do not need explicit width/height in most cases
seeAlso: visual.txt -- Background and border styling for Box elements
flexbox.txt -- How text nodes participate in flex layout

metadata.title: Transform System
metadata.description: The transform property for translating, rotating, scaling, and skewing elements.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact supports a transform object on any element's style for applying geometric
transformations. Transforms affect the visual rendering of the element without changing its
position in the layout tree. A transformed element still occupies the same layout space it
would without the transform -- sibling elements are not affected.

The transform system supports translation, rotation, scaling, and skewing. Transform origin
defaults to the center of the element (0.5, 0.5) and can be adjusted with originX and
originY values ranging from 0 (top-left) to 1 (bottom-right). Transforms are commonly
combined with the animation system for motion effects.
sections.api:
Transform style property:

  transform: {
    translateX?: number     // Horizontal offset in pixels
    translateY?: number     // Vertical offset in pixels
    rotate?: number         // Rotation in degrees (clockwise)
    scaleX?: number         // Horizontal scale factor (1 = no change)
    scaleY?: number         // Vertical scale factor (1 = no change)
    skewX?: number          // Horizontal skew in degrees
    skewY?: number          // Vertical skew in degrees
    originX?: number        // Transform origin X, 0-1 (default: 0.5 = center)
    originY?: number        // Transform origin Y, 0-1 (default: 0.5 = center)
  }

All transform sub-properties are optional. Only the properties you specify are applied.

Transform origin:
  originX and originY are normalized values from 0 to 1, where:
    0, 0 = top-left corner
    0.5, 0.5 = center (default)
    1, 1 = bottom-right corner

examples.title: Simple translation
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#89b4fa',
  transform: { translateX: 50, translateY: 20 },
}} />

examples.title: Rotation from center
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f38ba8',
  transform: { rotate: 45 },
}} />

examples.title: Rotation from top-left corner
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1',
  transform: { rotate: 15, originX: 0, originY: 0 },
}} />

examples.title: Scale
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f9e2af',
  transform: { scaleX: 1.5, scaleY: 0.8 },
}} />

examples.title: Combined transforms
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#cba6f7',
  transform: {
    translateX: 30,
    translateY: 10,
    rotate: 10,
    scaleX: 1.2,
    scaleY: 1.2,
  },
}} />

examples.title: Animated transform with useSpring

criticalRules: Transforms do NOT affect layout -- the element still occupies its original layout rectangle
Transform origin defaults to center (0.5, 0.5), not top-left
Rotation is specified in degrees, not radians
Scale values of 1.0 mean no change -- 2.0 doubles the size, 0.5 halves it
Transforms are visual-only and commonly used with the animation system for motion effects
OriginX/originY are 0-1 normalized, not pixel values

metadata.title: Visual Styling
metadata.description: Background colors, borders, border radius, shadows, gradients, opacity, and other visual properties.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact provides a comprehensive set of visual styling properties for Box elements.
These include background colors, border styling (width, color, radius with per-corner and
per-side control), box shadows, linear gradients, opacity, overflow clipping, z-index
stacking, outlines, and visibility toggling.

Colors can be specified as CSS strings ("#ff0000", "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)") or as Love2D-style
number arrays [r, g, b, a] where each component is 0-1. The Color type accepts both formats
and the renderer converts as needed for each target.
sections.api:
Color type:
  type Color = string | [number, number, number, number?]

  String format: "#ff0000", "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)", "red"
  Array format: [1, 0, 0, 1] (Love2D-style, 0-1 range, alpha optional)

Background:

  backgroundColor: Color
    Fills the element background with a solid color.

  backgroundGradient: {
    direction: 'horizontal' | 'vertical' | 'diagonal',
    colors: [Color, Color]
  }
    Linear gradient background. Takes precedence over backgroundColor when set.
    'horizontal' goes left to right, 'vertical' top to bottom, 'diagonal' top-left to
    bottom-right.

Border:

  borderWidth: number
    Sets border width on all sides. Requires borderColor to be visible.

  borderColor: Color
    Color of the border. Only visible when borderWidth > 0.

  borderRadius: number
    Rounds all four corners uniformly.

  Per-side border width:
    borderTopWidth: number
    borderRightWidth: number
    borderBottomWidth: number
    borderLeftWidth: number

  Per-side border color:
    borderTopColor: Color
    borderRightColor: Color
    borderBottomColor: Color
    borderLeftColor: Color

  Per-corner border radius:
    borderTopLeftRadius: number
    borderTopRightRadius: number
    borderBottomLeftRadius: number
    borderBottomRightRadius: number

Shadow:

  shadowColor: Color
    Shadow color. If not set, no shadow is rendered.

  shadowOffsetX: number
    Horizontal shadow offset (default: 0).

  shadowOffsetY: number
    Vertical shadow offset (default: 0).

  shadowBlur: number
    Blur radius for the shadow (default: 0).

Outline:

  outlineColor: Color
    Color of the outline. Outlines render outside the element border.

  outlineWidth: number
    Width of the outline in pixels (default: 1 when outlineColor is set).

  outlineOffset: number
    Gap between the element border and the outline.

Stacking and visibility:

  opacity: number
    Element transparency, 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).

  overflow: 'visible' | 'hidden' | 'scroll'
    Controls whether child content that exceeds the element bounds is visible,
    clipped, or scrollable.

  zIndex: number
    Stacking order. Higher values render on top of lower values.

  visibility: 'visible' | 'hidden'
    Hides the element visually but it still occupies space in layout.
    Unlike display: 'none', hidden elements are not removed from the layout tree.

  display: 'flex' | 'none'
    Set to 'none' to completely remove from layout (no space occupied).

examples.title: Colored box with rounded corners
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#89b4fa',
  borderRadius: 12,
}} />

examples.title: Box with border
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  borderWidth: 2,
  borderColor: '#cba6f7',
  borderRadius: 8,
}} />

examples.title: Per-corner border radius
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f38ba8',
  borderTopLeftRadius: 20,
  borderTopRightRadius: 20,
  borderBottomLeftRadius: 0,
  borderBottomRightRadius: 0,
}} />

examples.title: Box shadow
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#cdd6f4',
