effectively zero unless flexGrow or alignItems: 'stretch' provides one.

Root containers must always use width: '100%', height: '100%' to fill the viewport. This
is the most common mistake in iLoveReact development and is enforced by the linter. Using
flexGrow: 1 on the root does not work because there is no parent container to grow into.
sections.api:
Sizing style properties:

  width: number | string
    Width in pixels (number) or percentage of parent ('50%', '100%').
    Box nodes have zero intrinsic width. Text nodes have intrinsic width from font measurement.

  height: number | string
    Height in pixels (number) or percentage of parent.
    Box nodes have zero intrinsic height. Text nodes have intrinsic height from fontSize.

  minWidth: number | string
    Minimum width constraint. The element will not shrink below this value.

  minHeight: number | string
    Minimum height constraint.

  maxWidth: number | string
    Maximum width constraint. The element will not grow beyond this value.

  maxHeight: number | string
    Maximum height constraint.

  aspectRatio: number
    Maintains a width-to-height ratio. For example, aspectRatio: 16/9 with width: 320
    produces height: 180. If only one dimension is set, the other is computed from the ratio.

examples.title: Root container filling viewport
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e' }}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 20, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Full viewport</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Fixed-size box
examples.code: <Box style={{ width: 200, height: 100, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa', borderRadius: 8 }} />

examples.title: Percentage-based sizing
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%' }}>
  <Box style={{ width: '50%', height: '30%', backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
</Box>

examples.title: Min/max constraints
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: '80%',
  minWidth: 200,
  maxWidth: 600,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f9e2af',
}} />

examples.title: Aspect ratio
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 320,
  aspectRatio: 16 / 9,
  backgroundColor: '#cba6f7',
  borderRadius: 8,
}} />

criticalRules: Root containers MUST use width: '100%', height: '100%' -- NOT flexGrow: 1
Box nodes have zero intrinsic width and height -- always specify dimensions or use flex sizing
Text nodes have intrinsic dimensions based on fontSize and content -- but you still MUST set fontSize
Pre-compute grid dimensions rather than relying on child content to infer container size
Percentage values are relative to the parent's computed dimension, not the viewport (unless the parent is the root)
seeAlso: spacing.txt -- Padding and margin affect effective size
critical-rules.txt -- Root sizing and other critical rules

metadata.title: Padding, Margin, and Gap
metadata.description: Spacing properties for controlling element padding, margin, and flex gap.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact supports padding (inner spacing), margin (outer spacing), and gap (spacing
between flex children). These work the same way as in CSS Flexbox: padding creates space
inside the element's border, margin creates space outside, and gap creates uniform spacing
between sibling children in a flex container.

All spacing values accept numbers (pixels on Love2D/web, character cells on grid targets)
or percentage strings. Shorthand properties (padding, margin) apply to all four sides, and
per-side properties (paddingLeft, marginTop, etc.) override the shorthand for specific sides.
sections.api:
Padding properties:

  padding: number | string
    Applies uniform padding to all four sides.

  paddingLeft: number | string
  paddingRight: number | string
  paddingTop: number | string
  paddingBottom: number | string
    Per-side padding. Overrides the shorthand `padding` for the specified side.

Margin properties:

  margin: number | string
    Applies uniform margin to all four sides.

  marginLeft: number | string
  marginRight: number | string
  marginTop: number | string
  marginBottom: number | string
    Per-side margin. Overrides the shorthand `margin` for the specified side.

Gap property:

  gap: number | string
    Spacing between children along the main axis of a flex container.
    Applied between each pair of adjacent children.

examples.title: Uniform padding
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: '100%',
  height: '100%',
  padding: 24,
  backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e',
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>
    {`24px of space on all sides`}
  </Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Per-side padding
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 300,
  height: 100,
  paddingLeft: 20,
  paddingRight: 20,
  paddingTop: 8,
  paddingBottom: 8,
  backgroundColor: '#313244',
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Asymmetric padding</Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Margin for spacing between siblings
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', padding: 16 }}>
  <Box style={{ height: 50, marginBottom: 12, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, marginBottom: 12, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
</Box>

examples.title: Gap for uniform child spacing
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', padding: 16, gap: 12 }}>
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ height: 50, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
</Box>

examples.title: Row with gap
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  flexDirection: 'row',
  width: '100%',
  gap: 8,
  padding: 16,
}}>
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#f38ba8' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1' }} />
  <Box style={{ width: 80, height: 80, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa' }} />
</Box>

criticalRules: Padding reduces the available content area inside an element
Margin does not collapse in Flexbox layout (unlike CSS block layout)
Gap is applied between children only, not before the first or after the last child
Per-side properties (paddingLeft, marginTop, etc.) override the shorthand for that side
Percentage spacing values are relative to the parent container's width (matching CSS behavior)
seeAlso: flexbox.txt -- Flexbox layout and gap usage
sizing.txt -- How sizing interacts with padding
visual.txt -- Border width also affects content area

metadata.title: Text-Specific Style Properties
metadata.description: Styling properties for the Text primitive, including font, color, alignment, and decoration.

sections.overview:
The Text primitive has its own set of style properties for controlling typography. The most
important rule in iLoveReact is that every Text element MUST have an explicit fontSize in
its style. This is not optional -- the layout engine needs fontSize to measure text and
compute layout, and the linter will block builds that violate this rule.

Text styling covers font properties (size, family, weight), text layout (alignment,
overflow, line height, letter spacing), text decoration (underline, strikethrough), and
text shadow. Colors use the same Color type as visual styling (CSS strings or Love2D-style
arrays).
sections.api:
Text style properties:

  color: Color
    Text color. Accepts CSS strings ("#cdd6f4") or Love2D arrays ([0.8, 0.84, 0.96]).

  fontSize: number (REQUIRED)
    Font size in pixels (Love2D/web) or character scale (grid targets).
    This property is MANDATORY on every Text element. The linter enforces this with the
    'no-text-without-fontsize' rule.

  fontFamily: string
    Font family name. On Love2D, this must be a font file available in the project.
    On web, it maps to CSS font-family.

  fontWeight: 'normal' | 'bold' | number
    Font weight. 'normal' is typically 400, 'bold' is 700. Numeric values (100-900)
    are supported on web and Love2D (if the font file supports weight variants).

  textAlign: 'left' | 'center' | 'right'
    Horizontal text alignment within the Text element's bounds.
    Default: 'left'

  textOverflow: 'clip' | 'ellipsis'
    How to handle text that overflows its container.
    'clip': text is cut off at the boundary.
    'ellipsis': text is truncated with "..." at the boundary.

  textDecorationLine: 'none' | 'underline' | 'line-through'
    Text decoration. 'underline' draws a line below the text, 'line-through' draws
    a line through the middle.

  lineHeight: number
    Line height in pixels. Controls the vertical spacing between lines of text.
    On web, this is converted to CSS line-height with 'px' units.

  letterSpacing: number
    Additional horizontal space between characters, in pixels.

  textShadowColor: Color
    Color of the text shadow. If not set, no text shadow is rendered.

  textShadowOffsetX: number
    Horizontal offset of the text shadow.

  textShadowOffsetY: number
    Vertical offset of the text shadow.

examples.title: Basic text with required fontSize
examples.code: <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Hello, world</Text>

examples.title: Styled heading
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 32,
  fontWeight: 'bold',
  color: '#cba6f7',
  textAlign: 'center',
  letterSpacing: 2,
}}>
  Dashboard
</Text>

examples.title: Text with decoration
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 14,
  color: '#a6adc8',
  textDecorationLine: 'underline',
}}>
  Click here for details
</Text>

examples.title: Multiline text with lineHeight
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 14,
  color: '#cdd6f4',
  lineHeight: 22,
}}>
  {`This is a longer paragraph of text that demonstrates line height control. Each line has 22 pixels of vertical space.`}
</Text>

examples.title: Text overflow with ellipsis
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: 200 }}>
  <Text style={{
    fontSize: 14,
    color: '#cdd6f4',
    textOverflow: 'ellipsis',
  }}>
    {`This is a very long string that will be truncated with an ellipsis`}
  </Text>
</Box>

examples.title: Text shadow
examples.code:
<Text style={{
  fontSize: 24,
  color: '#cdd6f4',
  textShadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
  textShadowOffsetX: 2,
  textShadowOffsetY: 2,
}}>
  Shadow Text
</Text>

criticalRules: Every Text element MUST have explicit fontSize -- builds will fail without it (linter rule: no-text-without-fontsize)
Do NOT mix literal text and JSX expressions in Text children -- use template literals instead (linter rule: no-mixed-text-children)
WRONG: <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>Score: {score}</Text>
RIGHT: <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>{`Score: ${score}`}</Text>
Do NOT use the block character (U+2588) in Text elements -- it renders as a font glyph, not a filled pixel (linter rule: no-block-char-in-text)
Text nodes have intrinsic dimensions from font measurement -- they do not need explicit width/height in most cases
seeAlso: visual.txt -- Background and border styling for Box elements
flexbox.txt -- How text nodes participate in flex layout

metadata.title: Transform System
metadata.description: The transform property for translating, rotating, scaling, and skewing elements.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact supports a transform object on any element's style for applying geometric
transformations. Transforms affect the visual rendering of the element without changing its
position in the layout tree. A transformed element still occupies the same layout space it
would without the transform -- sibling elements are not affected.

The transform system supports translation, rotation, scaling, and skewing. Transform origin
defaults to the center of the element (0.5, 0.5) and can be adjusted with originX and
originY values ranging from 0 (top-left) to 1 (bottom-right). Transforms are commonly
combined with the animation system for motion effects.
sections.api:
Transform style property:

  transform: {
    translateX?: number     // Horizontal offset in pixels
    translateY?: number     // Vertical offset in pixels
    rotate?: number         // Rotation in degrees (clockwise)
    scaleX?: number         // Horizontal scale factor (1 = no change)
    scaleY?: number         // Vertical scale factor (1 = no change)
    skewX?: number          // Horizontal skew in degrees
    skewY?: number          // Vertical skew in degrees
    originX?: number        // Transform origin X, 0-1 (default: 0.5 = center)
    originY?: number        // Transform origin Y, 0-1 (default: 0.5 = center)
  }

All transform sub-properties are optional. Only the properties you specify are applied.

Transform origin:
  originX and originY are normalized values from 0 to 1, where:
    0, 0 = top-left corner
    0.5, 0.5 = center (default)
    1, 1 = bottom-right corner

examples.title: Simple translation
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#89b4fa',
  transform: { translateX: 50, translateY: 20 },
}} />

examples.title: Rotation from center
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f38ba8',
  transform: { rotate: 45 },
}} />

examples.title: Rotation from top-left corner
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#a6e3a1',
  transform: { rotate: 15, originX: 0, originY: 0 },
}} />

examples.title: Scale
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f9e2af',
  transform: { scaleX: 1.5, scaleY: 0.8 },
}} />

examples.title: Combined transforms
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 100,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#cba6f7',
  transform: {
    translateX: 30,
    translateY: 10,
    rotate: 10,
    scaleX: 1.2,
    scaleY: 1.2,
  },
}} />

examples.title: Animated transform with useSpring

criticalRules: Transforms do NOT affect layout -- the element still occupies its original layout rectangle
Transform origin defaults to center (0.5, 0.5), not top-left
Rotation is specified in degrees, not radians
Scale values of 1.0 mean no change -- 2.0 doubles the size, 0.5 halves it
Transforms are visual-only and commonly used with the animation system for motion effects
OriginX/originY are 0-1 normalized, not pixel values

metadata.title: Visual Styling
metadata.description: Background colors, borders, border radius, shadows, gradients, opacity, and other visual properties.

sections.overview:
iLoveReact provides a comprehensive set of visual styling properties for Box elements.
These include background colors, border styling (width, color, radius with per-corner and
per-side control), box shadows, linear gradients, opacity, overflow clipping, z-index
stacking, outlines, and visibility toggling.

Colors can be specified as CSS strings ("#ff0000", "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)") or as Love2D-style
number arrays [r, g, b, a] where each component is 0-1. The Color type accepts both formats
and the renderer converts as needed for each target.
sections.api:
Color type:
  type Color = string | [number, number, number, number?]

  String format: "#ff0000", "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)", "red"
  Array format: [1, 0, 0, 1] (Love2D-style, 0-1 range, alpha optional)

Background:

  backgroundColor: Color
    Fills the element background with a solid color.

  backgroundGradient: {
    direction: 'horizontal' | 'vertical' | 'diagonal',
    colors: [Color, Color]
  }
    Linear gradient background. Takes precedence over backgroundColor when set.
    'horizontal' goes left to right, 'vertical' top to bottom, 'diagonal' top-left to
    bottom-right.

Border:

  borderWidth: number
    Sets border width on all sides. Requires borderColor to be visible.

  borderColor: Color
    Color of the border. Only visible when borderWidth > 0.

  borderRadius: number
    Rounds all four corners uniformly.

  Per-side border width:
    borderTopWidth: number
    borderRightWidth: number
    borderBottomWidth: number
    borderLeftWidth: number

  Per-side border color:
    borderTopColor: Color
    borderRightColor: Color
    borderBottomColor: Color
    borderLeftColor: Color

  Per-corner border radius:
    borderTopLeftRadius: number
    borderTopRightRadius: number
    borderBottomLeftRadius: number
    borderBottomRightRadius: number

Shadow:

  shadowColor: Color
    Shadow color. If not set, no shadow is rendered.

  shadowOffsetX: number
    Horizontal shadow offset (default: 0).

  shadowOffsetY: number
    Vertical shadow offset (default: 0).

  shadowBlur: number
    Blur radius for the shadow (default: 0).

Outline:

  outlineColor: Color
    Color of the outline. Outlines render outside the element border.

  outlineWidth: number
    Width of the outline in pixels (default: 1 when outlineColor is set).

  outlineOffset: number
    Gap between the element border and the outline.

Stacking and visibility:

  opacity: number
    Element transparency, 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).

  overflow: 'visible' | 'hidden' | 'scroll'
    Controls whether child content that exceeds the element bounds is visible,
    clipped, or scrollable.

  zIndex: number
    Stacking order. Higher values render on top of lower values.

  visibility: 'visible' | 'hidden'
    Hides the element visually but it still occupies space in layout.
    Unlike display: 'none', hidden elements are not removed from the layout tree.

  display: 'flex' | 'none'
    Set to 'none' to completely remove from layout (no space occupied).

examples.title: Colored box with rounded corners
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#89b4fa',
  borderRadius: 12,
}} />

examples.title: Box with border
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  borderWidth: 2,
  borderColor: '#cba6f7',
  borderRadius: 8,
}} />

examples.title: Per-corner border radius
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#f38ba8',
  borderTopLeftRadius: 20,
  borderTopRightRadius: 20,
  borderBottomLeftRadius: 0,
  borderBottomRightRadius: 0,
}} />

examples.title: Box shadow
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 200,
  height: 100,
  backgroundColor: '#cdd6f4',
  shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3)',
  shadowOffsetX: 4,
  shadowOffsetY: 4,
  shadowBlur: 8,
  borderRadius: 8,
}} />

examples.title: Linear gradient
examples.code:
<Box style={{
  width: 300,
  height: 100,
  backgroundGradient: {
    direction: 'horizontal',
    colors: ['#f38ba8', '#89b4fa'],
  },
  borderRadius: 8,
}} />

examples.title: Opacity and z-index
examples.code:
<Box style={{ width: 200, height: 200, position: 'relative' }}>
  <Box style={{
    position: 'absolute',
    width: 150,
    height: 150,
    top: 0,
    left: 0,
    backgroundColor: '#f38ba8',
    zIndex: 1,
  }} />
  <Box style={{
    position: 'absolute',
    width: 150,
    height: 150,
    top: 50,
    left: 50,
    backgroundColor: '#89b4fa',
    opacity: 0.7,
    zIndex: 2,
  }} />
</Box>

criticalRules: borderWidth alone does not produce a visible border -- you must also set borderColor
backgroundGradient takes precedence over backgroundColor
overflow: 'hidden' clips children that extend beyond the element bounds
visibility: 'hidden' hides the element but it still occupies space (use display: 'none' to remove from layout)
Shadow rendering depends on the target platform (not available on all grid targets)
Colors can use either string format ("#ff0000") or array format ([1, 0, 0, 1])

metadata.title: BarChart
metadata.description: Vertical bar chart that renders data as proportionally sized colored bars with optional labels and values.

sections.overview:
BarChart renders a vertical bar chart from an array of data points. Each bar's height is proportional to its value relative to the maximum value in the dataset. Bars can have individual colors or share a default color.

The component renders entirely with Box and Text primitives, so it works on all targets. An optional label row appears below the bars, and values can be shown above each bar.
sections.api:
Import: import { BarChart } from '@ilovereact/core';

BarChartBar type:
```ts
interface BarChartBar {
  label: string;
  value: number;
  color?: Color;
}
```

Usage:
```tsx
<BarChart
  data={[
    { label: 'Mon', value: 12 },
    { label: 'Tue', value: 28 },
    { label: 'Wed', value: 19 },
    { label: 'Thu', value: 35 },
    { label: 'Fri', value: 24 },
  ]}
  height={100}
/>
```

Props:

| Prop       | Type            | Default    | Description                                |
|------------|-----------------|------------|--------------------------------------------|
| data       | BarChartBar[]   | (required) | Array of bar data points                   |
| height     | number          | 120        | Chart area height in pixels                |
| barWidth   | number          | 20         | Width of each bar in pixels                |
| gap        | number          | 8          | Gap between bars in pixels                 |
| showLabels | boolean         | true       | Show label text below each bar             |
| showValues | boolean         | false      | Show value text above each bar             |
| color      | Color           | '#3b82f6'  | Default bar color (overridden per-bar)     |
| style      | Style           | -          | Outer container style overrides            |

examples.title: Basic bar chart
examples.code:
```tsx
<BarChart
  data={[
    { label: 'Q1', value: 40 },
    { label: 'Q2', value: 65 },
    { label: 'Q3', value: 52 },
    { label: 'Q4', value: 78 },
  ]}
/>
```

examples.title: Custom colors per bar with values
Wide bars with no labels

criticalRules: The `data` prop is required. An empty array renders an empty placeholder.
Bar heights are relative to the maximum value in the data. If all values are equal, all bars render at full height.
If `maxValue` is 0 (all values are 0), bars are normalized against 1, so they appear as minimum height (1px).
Per-bar `color` overrides the component-level `color` prop for that specific bar.
BarChart does not handle negative values. All values should be non-negative.

metadata.title: Box
metadata.description: Fundamental flexbox layout container for all visual structure

sections.overview:
Box is the fundamental layout primitive in iLoveReact. Every visual structure is built from nested Box elements. It renders as a flexbox container with configurable direction, alignment, spacing, and visual styling. In web mode it outputs a `<div>` with CSS flexbox; in native mode it outputs a `'View'` host element processed by the Lua layout engine.

Box also serves as the primary event target. It accepts handlers for pointer, keyboard, touch, gamepad, and drag interactions. For higher-level interaction patterns (press state tracking, long press, hover callbacks), use Pressable instead, which wraps Box internally.
sections.api:
```tsx
import { Box } from '@ilovereact/core';
```

```tsx
<Box
  style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', flexDirection: 'column', backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e' }}
  hoverStyle={{ backgroundColor: '#313244' }}
  activeStyle={{ backgroundColor: '#45475a' }}
  onClick={(event) => { /* handle click */ }}
>
  {children}
</Box>
```

Props:
| Prop            | Type                            | Default   | Description                          |
|-----------------|---------------------------------|-----------|--------------------------------------|
| style           | Style                           | undefined | Flexbox layout and visual styling    |
| hoverStyle      | Style                           | undefined | Style merged on pointer hover        |
| activeStyle     | Style                           | undefined | Style merged on press/active         |
| onClick         | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Click/press handler                  |
| onRelease       | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Release handler                      |
| onPointerEnter  | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Pointer enters the box               |
| onPointerLeave  | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Pointer leaves the box               |
| onKeyDown       | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Key pressed while focused            |
| onKeyUp         | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Key released while focused           |
| onTextInput     | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Text input while focused             |
| onWheel         | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Mouse wheel / scroll wheel           |
| onTouchStart    | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Touch began                          |
| onTouchEnd      | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Touch ended                          |
| onTouchMove     | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Touch moved                          |
| onGamepadPress  | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Gamepad button pressed               |
| onGamepadRelease| (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Gamepad button released              |
| onGamepadAxis   | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Gamepad axis moved                   |
| onDragStart     | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Drag gesture began                   |
| onDrag          | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Drag gesture moved                   |
| onDragEnd       | (event: LoveEvent) => void      | undefined | Drag gesture ended                   |
| children        | ReactNode                       | undefined | Child elements                       |

The `style` prop accepts the full Style type, which includes flexbox properties (flexDirection, justifyContent, alignItems, flexGrow, flexShrink, flexBasis, flexWrap, gap), sizing (width, height, minWidth, minHeight, maxWidth, maxHeight, aspectRatio), spacing (padding*, margin*), visual (backgroundColor, borderRadius, borderWidth, borderColor, opacity, overflow, boxShadow), positioning (position, top/right/bottom/left, zIndex), gradients, transforms, transitions, and animations.

Default flexDirection is 'column'. Default display is 'flex'.

examples.title: Root container filling the viewport
examples.code:
```tsx
<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e' }}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 24, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Hello</Text>
</Box>
```

examples.title: Horizontal row with centered, spaced children
examples.code:
```tsx
<Box style={{
  width: '100%',
  flexDirection: 'row',
  justifyContent: 'space-between',
  alignItems: 'center',
  padding: 16,
}}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Left</Text>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Right</Text>
</Box>
```

examples.title: Interactive box with hover and active states
Drag-enabled box

platformNotes.Love2D: Renders as a 'View' host element. Layout computed by layout.lua (yoga-like flexbox). Visual rendering by painter.lua. Supports all style properties including gradients, transforms, box shadows, and per-corner border radii. The Lua painter handles hover/active style merging on the native side for smooth interaction without JS round-trips.
platformNotes.Web: Renders as a <div> with CSS flexbox. Style is converted via styleToCSS(). The web renderer uses React state for hover/active style merging. Drag handlers use pointer capture for reliable cross-element dragging. Keyboard handlers automatically set tabIndex=0 for focus.
platformNotes.Terminal: Grid targets use <view> lowercase intrinsic, not the Box component. Layout is handled by @ilovereact/grid.

criticalRules: Root containers MUST have width: '100%' and height: '100%'. Using flexGrow: 1 on the root will produce a zero-height container because there is no parent with a known size to grow into.

Row-direction Boxes (flexDirection: 'row') MUST have an explicit width for justifyContent to work. Box nodes have no intrinsic width (only Text nodes do), so without a width the container collapses and justifyContent has nothing to distribute.
Do not use flexGrow without sibling sizing context. flexGrow only works when the parent has a known size and there are siblings that establish the remaining space.
Default flexDirection is 'column'. If you expect horizontal layout, set flexDirection: 'row' explicitly.
Keep flex trees shallow. Prefer a single Box with flexDirection: 'row' over multiple nested wrapper Boxes. Deep hierarchies slow down layout computation.
Love2D is a fixed canvas, not a scrolling page. Fill the viewport; do not leave empty space expecting it to scroll.

metadata.title: Breadcrumbs
metadata.description: Navigation breadcrumb trail with clickable path segments and configurable separator.

sections.overview:
Breadcrumbs renders a horizontal trail of navigation items separated by a configurable separator character. Each item except the last is clickable via Pressable and triggers the `onSelect` callback with the item's id. The last item in the trail is displayed as bold text, indicating the current location.

The component is built with Box, Text, and Pressable primitives, making it work identically across all targets.

examples.title: Basic breadcrumbs
Custom separator
examples.code:
```tsx
<Breadcrumbs
  items={path}
  onSelect={navigateTo}
  separator=">"
/>
```

examples.title: Single item (current page only)
examples.code:
```tsx
<Breadcrumbs items={[{ id: 'home', label: 'Home' }]} />
```

criticalRules: The `items` prop is required. An empty array renders nothing.
The last item in the array is always rendered as non-clickable bold text. It does not trigger `onSelect`.
Only non-last items are wrapped in Pressable. The last item is a plain Text element.
Breadcrumbs renders in a row layout. Ensure the parent container has enough width for the trail, or items will wrap depending on the parent's flexWrap setting.

metadata.title: Checkbox
metadata.description: A toggleable checkbox with optional label, supporting controlled and uncontrolled modes.

sections.overview:
Checkbox is a square toggle control that displays a filled inner square when checked. It optionally renders a text label to the right of the checkbox.

Checkbox supports both controlled and uncontrolled modes. Pass `value` for controlled behavior, or use `defaultValue` for uncontrolled. The checkbox box border color changes between `color` (checked) and `uncheckedColor` (unchecked), and the box fills with `color` when checked with a white inner indicator.
sections.api:
Import: import { Checkbox } from '@ilovereact/core';

Usage:
```tsx
<Checkbox
  value={accepted}
  onValueChange={(v) => setAccepted(v)}
  label="Accept terms"
/>
```

Props:

| Prop           | Type                       | Default    | Description                              |
|----------------|----------------------------|------------|------------------------------------------|
| value          | boolean                    | -          | Controlled value. Omit for uncontrolled  |
| defaultValue   | boolean                    | false      | Initial value in uncontrolled mode       |
| onValueChange  | (value: boolean) => void   | -          | Called when the checkbox is toggled       |
| disabled       | boolean                    | false      | Disables interaction and dims opacity    |
| label          | string                     | -          | Text label rendered beside the checkbox  |
| size           | number                     | 20         | Checkbox box size in pixels              |
| color          | Color                      | '#3b82f6'  | Border and fill color when checked       |
| uncheckedColor | Color                      | '#6b7280'  | Border color when unchecked              |
| style          | Style                      | -          | Container style overrides                |

examples.title: Basic controlled checkbox with label
Uncontrolled with custom colors
examples.code:
```tsx
<Checkbox
  defaultValue={true}
  color="#22c55e"
  uncheckedColor="#94a3b8"
  size={24}
  label="Remember me"
/>
```

examples.title: Disabled checkbox
examples.code:
```tsx
<Checkbox value={false} disabled label="Unavailable option" />
```

criticalRules: The `size` prop controls only the checkbox square, not the label text size.
When `disabled` is true, opacity is set to 0.5 and click events are ignored.
In controlled mode, the visual state does not change unless the parent updates `value` in response to `onValueChange`.

metadata.title: FlatList
metadata.description: Virtualized scrollable list that renders only visible items for efficient large dataset display.

sections.overview:
FlatList is a virtualized scrollable list component that renders only items visible within the scroll viewport plus a configurable buffer zone. It uses spacer elements above and below the visible window to maintain correct total scroll height without mounting every item in the data array.

FlatList supports vertical and horizontal scrolling, multi-column grid layouts, inverted lists, infinite scrolling via `onEndReached`, and imperative scrolling methods. It delegates all scrolling behavior to the ScrollView component internally. FlatList accepts a `ref` for imperative control via `scrollToIndex` and `scrollToOffset`.
sections.api:
Import: import { FlatList } from '@ilovereact/core';

Usage:
```tsx
<FlatList
  data={items}
  renderItem={({ item, index }) => (
    <Box style={{ height: 50, padding: 8 }}>
      <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>{item.name}</Text>
    </Box>
  )}
  itemHeight={50}
  style={{ height: 400 }}
/>
```

FlatListProps<T>:

| Prop                   | Type                                                  | Default  | Description                                        |
|------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|----------|----------------------------------------------------|
| data                   | T[]                                                   | (required)| Array of items to render                          |
| renderItem             | (info: { item: T; index: number }) => ReactNode       | (required)| Render function for each item                     |
| keyExtractor           | (item: T, index: number) => string                    | -        | Unique key for each item (defaults to index)       |
| horizontal             | boolean                                               | false    | Enable horizontal scrolling                        |
| itemHeight             | number                                                | -        | Fixed item height (for vertical lists)             |
| itemWidth              | number                                                | -        | Fixed item width (for horizontal lists)            |
| estimatedItemSize      | number                                                | 50       | Estimated item size when exact size is unknown     |
| onEndReached           | () => void                                            | -        | Called when scroll nears the end of the list       |
| onEndReachedThreshold  | number                                                | 0.5      | Distance from end (in viewports) to trigger        |
| onScroll               | (event: ScrollEvent) => void                          | -        | Called on every scroll position change              |
| ListHeaderComponent    | ReactNode                                             | -        | Component rendered before the first item           |
| ListFooterComponent    | ReactNode                                             | -        | Component rendered after the last item             |
| ListEmptyComponent     | ReactNode                                             | -        | Component rendered when data is empty              |
| ItemSeparatorComponent | ReactNode                                             | -        | Component rendered between items                   |
| style                  | Style                                                 | -        | Outer ScrollView container style                   |
| contentContainerStyle  | Style                                                 | -        | Inner content container style                      |
| initialNumToRender     | number                                                | 10       | Number of items to render on first mount           |
| windowSize             | number                                                | 5        | Number of viewports to keep rendered (buffer)      |
| maxToRenderPerBatch    | number                                                | 10       | Max items to render per batch update               |
| inverted               | boolean                                               | false    | Reverses the item order                            |
| numColumns             | number                                                | -        | Number of columns for grid layout                  |

FlatListRef (via React.forwardRef):

| Method         | Signature                                              | Description                           |
|----------------|--------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------|
| scrollToIndex  | (params: { index: number; animated?: boolean }) => void| Scroll to a specific item by index    |
| scrollToOffset | (params: { offset: number; animated?: boolean }) => void| Scroll to a specific pixel offset    |

ScrollEvent type:
```ts
interface ScrollEvent {
  scrollX: number;
  scrollY: number;
  contentWidth: number;
  contentHeight: number;
}
```

examples.title: Basic vertical list
Grid layout with numColumns
Infinite scroll with onEndReached

criticalRules: FlatList MUST have an explicit `height` (or parent with known height) in its style. Without it, the scroll container collapses and virtualization breaks.
For best virtualization performance, provide `itemHeight` (vertical) or `itemWidth` (horizontal). Without these, `estimatedItemSize` (default: 50) is used, which may cause visual jumping.
The `renderItem` function should return elements with a consistent, fixed height matching `itemHeight`. Variable-height items will cause virtualization misalignment.
`keyExtractor` defaults to using the array index as a string. For data that changes order or gets inserted/removed, always provide a stable `keyExtractor`.

metadata.title: Image
metadata.description: Displays images with sizing and objectFit control

sections.overview: Image displays an image from a file path or URL. It supports sizing via width/height style properties and content fitting via the objectFit style property. Unlike Box, Image has no children. Unlike Text, Image has no intrinsic size derived from content -- you must specify width and height explicitly or let the parent constrain it. In web mode, Image renders as an `` element. In native mode, it outputs an `'Image'` host element that the Lua painter draws using love.graphics.draw() with the image loaded from the src path.
sections.api:
```tsx
import { Image } from '@ilovereact/core';
```

```tsx
<Image
  src="assets/logo.png"
  style={{ width: 128, height: 128, objectFit: 'contain' }}
/>
```

Props:
| Prop    | Type                         | Default   | Description                          |
|---------|------------------------------|-----------|--------------------------------------|
| src     | string                       | REQUIRED  | Image file path or URL               |
| style   | Style                        | undefined | Sizing and visual styling            |
| onClick | (event: LoveEvent) => void   | undefined | Click/press handler                  |
| onWheel | (event: LoveEvent) => void   | undefined | Mouse wheel handler                  |

objectFit values (set via style.objectFit):
| Value   | Behavior                                                        |
|---------|-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| fill    | Stretch image to fill the element (may distort aspect ratio)    |
| contain | Scale image to fit entirely within the element (letterboxed)    |
| cover   | Scale image to cover the element entirely (may crop)            |
| none    | Display at original size, no scaling                            |

examples.title: Basic image with fixed size
examples.code:
```tsx
<Image
  src="assets/icon.png"
  style={{ width: 64, height: 64 }}
/>
```

examples.title: Image with objectFit contain
examples.code:
```tsx
<Image
  src="assets/banner.png"
  style={{
    width: '100%',
    height: 200,
    objectFit: 'contain',
    backgroundColor: '#181825',
  }}
/>
```

examples.title: Clickable image
examples.code:
```tsx
<Image
  src="assets/button-sprite.png"
  style={{ width: 48, height: 48, borderRadius: 8 }}
  onClick={() => console.log('image clicked')}
/>
```

examples.title: Cover image filling a card
examples.code:
```tsx
<Box style={{ width: 300, height: 200, borderRadius: 12, overflow: 'hidden' }}>
  <Image
    src="assets/photo.jpg"
    style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%', objectFit: 'cover' }}
  />
</Box>
```

platformNotes.Love2D: Renders as an 'Image' host element. The Lua painter loads the image via love.graphics.newImage() and caches it. The src path is relative to the project root (where main.lua lives). Supported formats: PNG, JPEG, BMP, TGA, and other formats Love2D supports. objectFit is implemented by the painter via quad scaling.
platformNotes.Web: Renders as an element with display: block. objectFit maps directly to the CSS object-fit property. src can be a relative path, absolute URL, or data URI.
platformNotes.Terminal: Image is not supported on grid targets. Terminal, ComputerCraft, Neovim, and other character-grid renderers cannot display raster images. Use colored Box elements to approximate pixel art if needed.

criticalRules: Image has no intrinsic size. You must provide width and height via the style prop, or constrain the image via a parent Box with known dimensions. An Image without sizing will collapse to zero.
The src prop is required. Omitting it will produce an error.
Image paths in Love2D are relative to the project root directory, not the source file. Use paths like "assets/image.png", not "../assets/image.png".
Image accepts no children. It is a leaf element.

metadata.title: Components Overview
metadata.description: Reference index for all iLoveReact primitives and components

sections.overview:
iLoveReact ships a set of universal primitives and higher-level components that work across all render targets. Every visible element on screen is built from these building blocks. Primitives are the lowest-level elements (Box, Text, Image) that map directly to host elements in each target. Components are composed from primitives and provide richer interaction patterns (Pressable, ScrollView, Modal, Slider, and others).

All primitives and components are exported from `@ilovereact/core`. Grid targets (terminal, ComputerCraft, Neovim, Hammerspoon, AwesomeWM) use lowercase JSX intrinsics (`<view>`, `<text>`) and typically define local wrapper components; the `@ilovereact/core` exports target Love2D and web renderers.

platformNotes.Love2D: All components render as string-typed host elements ('View', 'Text', 'Image') processed by the Lua layout engine and painter. Flexbox is computed by layout.lua. Events go through bridge_quickjs.lua.
platformNotes.Web:
Primitives render as DOM elements (div, span, img) with CSS flexbox. Interaction events use standard DOM event listeners. Styles are converted from the Style type to React.CSSProperties by styleToCSS().
Terminal / Grid targets:
Use lowercase intrinsics (<view>, <text>) with the grid layout engine. The @ilovereact/core components are not used directly; grid targets have their own component wrappers built on @ilovereact/grid.

criticalRules: Always import from '@ilovereact/core', never from internal package paths
Every <Text> must have an explicit fontSize -- the linter will block your build otherwise
Root containers need width: '100%' and height: '100%', not flexGrow: 1
Grid targets use different primitives; do not import @ilovereact/core components into grid-target code
Run `ilovereact lint` after any component change to catch layout violations early

metadata.title: Modal
metadata.description: Fullscreen overlay with backdrop, animations, and dismiss handling

sections.overview:
Modal displays content in a fullscreen overlay that sits above the rest of the UI. It renders through the Portal system, ensuring correct z-index layering regardless of where it appears in the component tree. Modal supports a customizable backdrop (color, transparency, click-to-dismiss), simple enter/exit animations (none, fade, slide), and Escape key dismissal.

Modal is a controlled component -- you manage visibility via the `visible` prop and handle close events via `onRequestClose`. The backdrop press and Escape key both trigger onRequestClose; the component does not close itself. This gives you full control over dismiss conditions (e.g., confirmation dialogs that ignore backdrop clicks).
sections.api:
```tsx
import { Modal } from '@ilovereact/core';
```

```tsx
const [showModal, setShowModal] = useState(false);

<Modal
  visible={showModal}
  onRequestClose={() => setShowModal(false)}
  animationType="fade"
>
  <Box style={{ width: 300, padding: 24, backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e', borderRadius: 12 }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 18, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Dialog Title</Text>
    <Pressable onPress={() => setShowModal(false)}>
      <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#89b4fa' }}>Close</Text>
    </Pressable>
  </Box>
</Modal>
```

Props:
| Prop            | Type                            | Default       | Description                                    |
|-----------------|---------------------------------|---------------|------------------------------------------------|
| visible         | boolean                         | REQUIRED      | Show or hide the modal                         |
| onRequestClose  | () => void                      | undefined     | Called on Escape key or backdrop press          |
| onShow          | () => void                      | undefined     | Called when modal finishes appearing            |
| animationType   | 'none' | 'fade' | 'slide'       | 'none'        | Enter/exit animation style                     |
| transparent     | boolean                         | false         | Use transparent backdrop (overrides color)      |
| backdropColor   | Color                           | [0,0,0,0.5]   | Backdrop color (RGBA or CSS string)            |
| backdropDismiss | boolean                         | true          | Whether backdrop press triggers onRequestClose |
| children        | ReactNode                       | REQUIRED      | Modal content                                  |
| style           | Style                           | undefined     | Applied to the content wrapper                 |

Animation types:
| Type  | Enter behavior                   | Exit behavior                    |
|-------|----------------------------------|----------------------------------|
| none  | Instant appear                   | Instant disappear                |
| fade  | Fades in from transparent        | Fades out to transparent         |
| slide | Slides up from below             | Slides down to below             |

Animation duration is 200ms for both enter and exit.

examples.title: Basic confirmation dialog
examples.code:
```tsx
const [show, setShow] = useState(false);

<Pressable onPress={() => setShow(true)}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#89b4fa' }}>Delete item</Text>
</Pressable>

<Modal visible={show} onRequestClose={() => setShow(false)} animationType="fade">
  <Box style={{
    width: 320,
    padding: 24,
    backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e',
    borderRadius: 12,
    gap: 16,
  }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 18, fontWeight: 'bold', color: '#cdd6f4' }}>
      Confirm Delete
    </Text>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#a6adc8' }}>
      Are you sure? This cannot be undone.
    </Text>
    <Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row', justifyContent: 'end', gap: 12, width: '100%' }}>
      <Pressable onPress={() => setShow(false)}>
        <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#a6adc8' }}>Cancel</Text>
      </Pressable>
      <Pressable onPress={() => { handleDelete(); setShow(false); }}>
        <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#f38ba8' }}>Delete</Text>
      </Pressable>
    </Box>
  </Box>
</Modal>
```

examples.title: Non-dismissable modal (ignores backdrop click)
examples.code:
```tsx
<Modal
  visible={isProcessing}
  backdropDismiss={false}
  backdropColor={[0, 0, 0, 0.8]}
>
  <Box style={{ padding: 32, backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e', borderRadius: 12, alignItems: 'center' }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Processing...</Text>
  </Box>
</Modal>
```

examples.title: Transparent overlay
examples.code:
```tsx
<Modal visible={showTooltip} transparent onRequestClose={() => setShowTooltip(false)}>
  <Box style={{
    position: 'absolute',
    top: 100,
    left: 200,
    padding: 8,
    backgroundColor: '#313244',
    borderRadius: 4,
  }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 12, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Tooltip content</Text>
  </Box>
</Modal>
```

examples.title: Slide-up modal with onShow callback
examples.code:
```tsx
<Modal
  visible={showPanel}
  onRequestClose={() => setShowPanel(false)}
  onShow={() => console.log('modal fully visible')}
  animationType="slide"
>
  <Box style={{
    width: '100%',
    height: '50%',
    backgroundColor: '#1e1e2e',
    borderRadius: 16,
    padding: 24,
  }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 20, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>Bottom Sheet</Text>
  </Box>
</Modal>
```

platformNotes.Love2D: Modal renders through the Portal system which places content at the top of the instance tree for z-index layering. The backdrop is a full-screen Pressable that intercepts clicks. Escape key handling is wired through the Box onKeyDown handler in native mode. Animations are stepped (4 steps over 200ms) rather than continuous -- adequate for modal transitions but not smooth enough for complex animation needs.
platformNotes.Web: Uses the Portal system (React portal to a PortalHost). The backdrop prevents body scroll by setting document.body.style.overflow = 'hidden'. Escape key handler uses document.addEventListener('keydown'). CSS transitions are used for fade/slide animations in addition to the stepped state machine. The web renderer restores the original body overflow on unmount.
platformNotes.Terminal: Not available on grid targets. For modal-like behavior on character-grid renderers, overlay a view with higher z-index and handle input routing manually.

criticalRules: Modal is controlled: it will not close itself. You must update the `visible` prop to false in your onRequestClose handler.
The `children` prop is required. A Modal with no children renders an empty overlay with just the backdrop.
Do not conditionally render Modal itself based on visibility -- always render it and control with `visible`. The component handles its own mount/unmount animation lifecycle internally.
When backdropDismiss is false, the only way to close the modal is programmatically or via Escape key (if onRequestClose is provided). Design your content with an explicit close control.
onShow fires after the enter animation completes, not when visible becomes true. For 'none' animation type, it fires immediately.
Modal uses Portal internally. You do not need to wrap it in a Portal yourself.

metadata.title: NavPanel
metadata.description: Sidebar navigation panel with grouped sections, active item highlighting, and optional header slot.

sections.overview:
NavPanel renders a vertical sidebar navigation component organized into titled sections. Each section contains a list of selectable items. The currently active item is highlighted with a distinct background and text color, and hovering over items provides visual feedback via Pressable.

An optional header slot renders arbitrary content at the top of the panel, separated from the sections by a divider line. NavPanel uses a fixed width by default but can be customized via the `width` prop or `style` overrides.

examples.title: Basic sidebar navigation
With header and multiple sections
Full-height sidebar in layout

criticalRules: The `sections` prop is required. An empty array renders only the background panel with optional header.
`activeId` is compared against each item's `id` for highlighting. If no item matches, no item is highlighted.
NavPanel has a fixed `width` (default 180). It does not grow to fill its container. Override with `style={{ flexGrow: 1 }}` or set an explicit `width` if needed.
The header slot renders any ReactNode. It is not affected by section styling.

metadata.title: Pressable
metadata.description: Interaction component with press, long press, and hover state tracking

sections.overview:
Pressable is a high-level interaction component that tracks pressed, hovered, and focused states. It wraps Box internally and provides callbacks for press, long press, hover, and focus events. Unlike Box's raw event handlers, Pressable manages interaction lifecycle: it fires onPress only on a clean release (not when a long press fires), supports configurable long press delay, and exposes interaction state to children via a render prop pattern.

Pressable supports both static and function-based style and children props. When passed a function, it receives a PressableState object with { pressed, hovered, focused } booleans, letting you build reactive UI without manual state management. It also supports hitSlop to expand the touch target beyond visible bounds, and integrates keyboard accessibility (Enter/Space triggers press).

examples.title: Simple button
examples.code:
```tsx
<Pressable
  onPress={() => console.log('pressed')}
  style={{ padding: 12, backgroundColor: '#89b4fa', borderRadius: 8 }}
>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#1e1e2e' }}>Submit</Text>
</Pressable>
```

examples.title: Reactive style and children via render props
Long press with expanded hit area
Disabled state

platformNotes.Love2D: In native mode, Pressable wraps a Box and passes interaction state and hitSlop as props to the host element. The Lua event system handles hit testing with hitSlop expansion. Long press timing runs in JavaScript via setTimeout.
platformNotes.Web: Renders as a <div> with pointer event handlers, tabIndex for keyboard focus, and role attribute for accessibility. Disabled state sets cursor: not-allowed and opacity: 0.5. HitSlop is implemented via negative margin + positive padding trick to expand the clickable area without changing visual bounds. Keyboard accessibility: Enter and Space trigger press.
platformNotes.Terminal: Not directly available on grid targets. Build equivalent interaction with the grid target's own event system.

criticalRules: onPress fires only on release and only if onLongPress did not fire during the same gesture. If you need to know immediately when the finger goes down, use onPressIn.
The children prop is required. Pressable with no children renders an empty, invisible touch target.
When disabled is true, all event handlers are suppressed and state resets to { pressed: false, hovered: false, focused: false }.
If pointer leaves the element while pressed, the press is canceled (pressed becomes false, long press timer is cleared).
hitSlop expands the interactive area, not the visual area. The element looks the same but responds to touches outside its visible bounds.

metadata.title: ProgressBar
metadata.description: Progress indicator bar that fills proportionally from 0 to 1, with optional label and animation.

sections.overview:
ProgressBar displays a horizontal fill bar representing progress from 0 to 1. The fill width is rendered as a percentage of the track width. An optional label shows the percentage or custom text, and the `animated` prop uses `useSpring` to smoothly interpolate value changes.

The component uses Box and Text primitives, making it compatible with all targets. The track and fill both use pill-shaped border radii based on the height.
sections.api:
Import: import { ProgressBar } from '@ilovereact/core';

Usage:
```tsx
<ProgressBar value={0.65} />
```

Props:

| Prop       | Type    | Default    | Description                                  |
|------------|---------|------------|----------------------------------------------|
| value      | number  | (required) | Progress value from 0 to 1                   |
| color      | Color   | '#3b82f6'  | Fill bar color                               |
| trackColor | Color   | '#1e293b'  | Background track color                       |
| height     | number  | 8          | Bar height in pixels                         |
| showLabel  | boolean | false      | Show percentage label (requires height >= 14)|
| label      | string  | -          | Custom label text (defaults to percentage)   |
| animated   | boolean | false      | Animate value changes with useSpring         |
| style      | Style   | -          | Outer container style overrides              |

examples.title: Basic progress bar
examples.code:
```tsx
<ProgressBar value={0.42} style={{ width: '100%' }} />
```

examples.title: Progress bar with label
Animated progress with custom label

criticalRules: The `value` prop is required and is clamped to the range [0, 1]. Values outside this range are clamped internally.
ProgressBar needs an explicit `width` either via the `style` prop or from its parent layout. Without width, the track collapses.
The `showLabel` prop is ignored when `height < 14` because the text would not fit within the bar.
When using `animated`, the `useSpring` hook is called unconditionally. The animation springs toward `value * 100` on every value change.

metadata.title: Radio / RadioGroup
metadata.description: Radio button with RadioGroup for exclusive single-selection within a group.

sections.overview:
Radio and RadioGroup work together for exclusive selection. RadioGroup wraps a set of Radio components and provides shared context so that selecting one Radio automatically deselects the others.

RadioGroup supports both controlled and uncontrolled modes. In controlled mode, pass `value` and respond to `onValueChange`. In uncontrolled mode, optionally set `defaultValue`. Each Radio reads the group state from React context and renders a circular indicator that fills when its value matches the group's selected value.
sections.api:
Import: import { Radio, RadioGroup } from '@ilovereact/core';

Usage:
```tsx
<RadioGroup value={selected} onValueChange={setSelected}>
  <Radio value="a" label="Option A" />
  <Radio value="b" label="Option B" />
  <Radio value="c" label="Option C" />
</RadioGroup>
```

RadioGroup Props:

| Prop          | Type                      | Default | Description                                |
|---------------|---------------------------|---------|--------------------------------------------|
| value         | string                    | -       | Controlled selected value                  |
| defaultValue  | string                    | -       | Initial value in uncontrolled mode         |
| onValueChange | (value: string) => void   | -       | Called when selection changes               |
| disabled      | boolean                   | false   | Disables all Radio children                |
| children      | ReactNode                 | -       | Radio components (required)                |
| style         | Style                     | -       | Container style overrides                  |

Radio Props:

| Prop           | Type    | Default    | Description                               |
|----------------|---------|------------|-------------------------------------------|
| value          | string  | (required) | Value this radio represents               |
| label          | string  | -          | Text label rendered beside the circle     |
| disabled       | boolean | false      | Disables this specific radio              |
| size           | number  | 20         | Circle diameter in pixels                 |
| color          | Color   | '#3b82f6'  | Border and inner dot color when selected  |
| uncheckedColor | Color   | '#6b7280'  | Border color when not selected            |
| style          | Style   | -          | Container style overrides                 |

examples.title: Controlled radio group
examples.code:
```tsx
const [plan, setPlan] = useState('free');

<RadioGroup value={plan} onValueChange={setPlan}>
  <Radio value="free" label="Free" />
  <Radio value="pro" label="Pro" />
  <Radio value="enterprise" label="Enterprise" />
</RadioGroup>
```

examples.title: Uncontrolled with custom styling
examples.code:
```tsx
<RadioGroup defaultValue="dark">
  <Radio value="light" label="Light" color="#f59e0b" size={24} />
  <Radio value="dark" label="Dark" color="#f59e0b" size={24} />
</RadioGroup>
```

examples.title: Disabled group
examples.code:
```tsx
<RadioGroup value="locked" disabled>
  <Radio value="locked" label="Locked option" />
  <Radio value="other" label="Other option" />
</RadioGroup>
```

criticalRules: Radio MUST be wrapped in a RadioGroup. A Radio rendered outside a RadioGroup will not respond to clicks.
The `value` prop on Radio is required and must be a string. It identifies which option this Radio represents within the group.
In controlled mode, the RadioGroup does not update its selection unless the parent updates the `value` prop in response to `onValueChange`.

metadata.title: ScrollView
metadata.description: Scrollable container with imperative scrollTo API

sections.overview:
ScrollView is a scrollable container that clips its children to its bounds and allows scrolling to reveal overflow content. It supports both vertical (default) and horizontal scrolling, optional scroll indicators, and scroll lifecycle callbacks. ScrollView also exposes an imperative scrollTo() method via React.forwardRef, letting you programmatically scroll to a specific position with optional animation.

In web mode, ScrollView renders as a `<div>` with overflow: auto and CSS-based scrolling. In native mode, it outputs a `'View'` host element with overflow: 'scroll', and the Lua layout engine handles scissor clipping, scroll translation, scrollbar rendering, and wheel event processing.

examples.title: Basic vertical scroll
examples.code:
```tsx
<ScrollView style={{ width: '100%', height: 200 }}>
  {Array.from({ length: 20 }, (_, i) => (
    <Box key={i} style={{ padding: 12, borderBottomWidth: 1, borderColor: '#313244' }}>
      <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>{`Item ${i + 1}`}</Text>
    </Box>
  ))}
</ScrollView>
```

examples.title: Horizontal scroll
examples.code:
```tsx
<ScrollView horizontal style={{ width: '100%', height: 100 }}>
  {Array.from({ length: 10 }, (_, i) => (
    <Box key={i} style={{ width: 120, height: 80, margin: 8, backgroundColor: '#313244', borderRadius: 8 }}>
      <Text style={{ fontSize: 12, color: '#cdd6f4' }}>{`Card ${i + 1}`}</Text>
    </Box>
  ))}
</ScrollView>
```

examples.title: Imperative scrollTo
examples.code:
```tsx
const scrollRef = React.useRef<ScrollViewRef>(null);

<Box style={{ width: '100%', height: '100%' }}>
  <Pressable onPress={() => scrollRef.current?.scrollTo({ y: 0, animated: true })}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 14, color: '#89b4fa' }}>Back to top</Text>
  </Pressable>

  <ScrollView ref={scrollRef} style={{ width: '100%', flexGrow: 1 }}>
    {/* long content */}
  </ScrollView>
</Box>
```

examples.title: Hidden scrollbar with scroll tracking

platformNotes.Love2D: The Lua layout engine implements scroll by translating child positions within a scissor-clipped region. Wheel events adjust scroll position. Scroll indicators are drawn as thin overlay rectangles by the painter. The imperative scrollTo() updates style.scrollX/scrollY which the layout engine reads on the next pass. Animated scrolling is handled natively in Lua.
platformNotes.Web: Uses native browser scrolling via overflow: auto. Horizontal mode sets overflowX: auto and overflowY: hidden (and vice versa for vertical). showScrollIndicator: false hides the scrollbar using scrollbarWidth: 'none' (Firefox) and msOverflowStyle: 'none' (legacy Edge). Webkit/Blink scrollbar hiding requires CSS pseudo-element styling not achievable via inline styles alone. The imperative scrollTo() calls element.scrollTo() with behavior: 'smooth' when animated is true. onScrollEnd is detected via 150ms debounce after the last scroll event.
platformNotes.Terminal: Not directly available on grid targets. Grid layouts are fixed-size and do not scroll. For large datasets on grid targets, use pagination or FlatList-style windowing.

criticalRules: ScrollView MUST have a constrained size (explicit width/height or parent constraints). Without a known size, there is nothing to overflow and nothing to scroll.
Do not nest ScrollViews in the same axis. A vertical ScrollView inside another vertical ScrollView creates ambiguous scroll targets. Cross-axis nesting (horizontal inside vertical) is acceptable.
When horizontal is true, the default flexDirection becomes 'row'. Children lay out left to right.
Use FlatList instead of ScrollView for long lists of uniform items. ScrollView renders all children; FlatList virtualizes off-screen items for performance.
The onScrollEnd callback fires after scrolling stops for 150ms. It is debounced, not instantaneous.

metadata.title: Select
metadata.description: Dropdown selection component with web-native select and native accordion-style expand/collapse.

sections.overview:
Select provides a dropdown-style selection from a list of options. Each option has a `label` (displayed) and a `value` (used programmatically).

Select supports both controlled and uncontrolled modes. In web mode, it renders a native HTML `<select>` element with custom styling. In native mode (Love2D), it renders an inline accordion: clicking the header toggles the option list open or closed, and clicking an option selects it and collapses the list.
sections.api:
Import: import { Select } from '@ilovereact/core';

SelectOption type:
```ts
interface SelectOption {
  label: string;
  value: string;
}
```

Usage:
```tsx
<Select
  value={selected}
  onValueChange={setSelected}
  options={[
    { label: 'Red', value: 'red' },
    { label: 'Green', value: 'green' },
    { label: 'Blue', value: 'blue' },
  ]}
/>
```

Props:

| Prop          | Type                      | Default      | Description                               |
|---------------|---------------------------|--------------|-------------------------------------------|
| value         | string                    | -            | Controlled selected value                 |
| defaultValue  | string                    | -            | Initial value in uncontrolled mode        |
| onValueChange | (value: string) => void   | -            | Called when selection changes              |
| options       | SelectOption[]            | (required)   | Array of { label, value } options         |
| placeholder   | string                    | 'Select...'  | Text shown when no option is selected     |
| disabled      | boolean                   | false        | Disables interaction and dims opacity     |
| style         | Style                     | -            | Container style overrides                 |
| color         | Color                     | '#3b82f6'    | Accent color for open state border        |

examples.title: Controlled select
Uncontrolled with default
examples.code:
```tsx
<Select
  defaultValue="dark"
  options={[
    { label: 'Light', value: 'light' },
    { label: 'Dark', value: 'dark' },
    { label: 'System', value: 'system' },
  ]}
/>
```

examples.title: Disabled select
examples.code:
```tsx
<Select
  value="locked"
  disabled
  options={[{ label: 'Locked', value: 'locked' }]}
/>
```

criticalRules: The `options` prop is required. Passing an empty array renders a header with the placeholder but no options to select.
In native mode, the open/close state is internal. There is no prop to force the dropdown open.
When `disabled` is true, opacity is set to 0.5 and both the toggle and option clicks are ignored.

metadata.title: Slider
metadata.description: Draggable range input with track and thumb for value selection

sections.overview:
Slider provides a draggable input for selecting a numeric value within a range. It renders a track with an active fill and a draggable thumb. Slider supports both controlled (value prop) and uncontrolled (defaultValue prop) modes, step snapping, vertical orientation, and full visual customization of track and thumb colors and sizes.

In web mode, Slider handles drag via mouse events with global listeners for reliable tracking outside the element bounds. In native mode, it uses the Box drag event system (onDragStart, onDrag, onDragEnd) for pointer tracking. The native renderer uses a three-segment flex layout (active track, thumb, inactive track) rather than absolute positioning for compatibility with the Lua layout engine.
sections.api:
```tsx
import { Slider } from '@ilovereact/core';
```

```tsx
const [volume, setVolume] = useState(0.5);

<Slider
  value={volume}
  onValueChange={setVolume}
  minimumValue={0}
  maximumValue={1}
  step={0.1}
  style={{ width: 200 }}
/>
```

Props:
| Prop             | Type                          | Default     | Description                                |
|------------------|-------------------------------|-------------|--------------------------------------------|
| value            | number                        | undefined   | Controlled value (overrides internal state)|
| defaultValue     | number                        | 0           | Initial value for uncontrolled mode        |
| onValueChange    | (value: number) => void       | undefined   | Called on every value change during drag    |
| onSlidingStart   | () => void                    | undefined   | Called when drag begins                    |
| onSlidingEnd     | (value: number) => void       | undefined   | Called when drag ends with final value     |
| minimumValue     | number                        | 0           | Minimum allowed value                      |
| maximumValue     | number                        | 1           | Maximum allowed value                      |
| step             | number                        | undefined   | Snap value to step increments              |
| disabled         | boolean                       | false       | Disable interaction                        |
| style            | Style                         | undefined   | Container style (width sets track length)  |
| trackColor       | Color                         | '#333333'   | Inactive track color                       |
| activeTrackColor | Color                         | '#4A90D9'   | Active (filled) track color                |
| thumbColor       | Color                         | '#ffffff'   | Thumb color                                |
| thumbSize        | number                        | 20          | Thumb diameter in pixels                   |
| trackHeight      | number                        | 4           | Track height in pixels                     |
| vertical         | boolean                       | false       | Vertical orientation                       |

examples.title: Basic horizontal slider
Stepped slider with custom colors
Uncontrolled slider with callbacks
Vertical slider
Disabled slider
examples.code:
```tsx
<Slider
  value={0.3}
  disabled
  style={{ width: 200 }}
/>
```

platformNotes.Love2D: Native mode uses a three-segment flex row layout: active track segment, thumb circle, inactive track segment. This avoids position: absolute which has limitations in the Lua layout engine for this use case. Drag tracking uses the Box drag event system (onDragStart, onDrag, onDragEnd) with totalDeltaX/totalDeltaY from the LoveEvent. Track width defaults to 200px if not specified via style.width. The value-at-drag-start is captured and deltas are applied relative to it for smooth, predictable dragging.
platformNotes.Web: Uses absolute positioning for the active track fill and thumb within the track container. Mouse events use global document listeners (mousemove, mouseup) during drag for reliable tracking even when the cursor leaves the slider bounds. Disabled state shows cursor: not-allowed on the thumb.
platformNotes.Terminal: Not available on grid targets. For value selection on character-grid renderers, build a custom component using keyboard input.

criticalRules: In controlled mode (value prop provided), you MUST update the value in onValueChange. If you do not, the thumb will not move because the component re-renders with the stale controlled value.
The style.width prop (or style.height for vertical) determines the track length. Without it, the slider defaults to 200px. Always set an explicit size for predictable layout.
step snapping rounds to the nearest step increment. A step of 0.1 with range 0-1 produces values: 0, 0.1, 0.2, ..., 1.0. The snapped value is clamped to [minimumValue, maximumValue].

onValueChange fires on every drag movement (potentially many times per second). Do not perform expensive operations in this callback. Use onSlidingEnd for final-value operations like network requests or heavy state updates.
onSlidingEnd fires once when the drag gesture completes. Its argument is the final value after step snapping and clamping.
Disabled sliders render at 50% opacity and ignore all interaction.

metadata.title: Sparkline
metadata.description: Mini inline chart rendered as vertical bars normalized to the min/max of the data.

sections.overview:
Sparkline renders a compact inline chart from an array of numbers. Each data point is represented as a thin vertical bar whose height is proportional to the value's position between the dataset's minimum and maximum. This creates a quick visual representation of trends or distributions within a small footprint.

Unlike BarChart, Sparkline is designed for inline use where labels and axes are unnecessary. It automatically computes bar widths to fit the given width and normalizes heights against the data range.
sections.api:
Import: import { Sparkline } from '@ilovereact/core';

Usage:
```tsx
<Sparkline data={[3, 7, 2, 9, 4, 6, 8, 1, 5]} />
```

Props:

| Prop   | Type     | Default    | Description                     |
|--------|----------|------------|---------------------------------|
| data   | number[] | (required) | Array of numeric data points    |
| width  | number   | 80         | Total chart width in pixels     |
| height | number   | 24         | Total chart height in pixels    |
| color  | Color    | '#3b82f6'  | Bar color                       |
| style  | Style    | -          | Container style overrides       |

examples.title: Custom size and color
Inline with text
examples.code:
```tsx
<Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row', alignItems: 'center', gap: 8 }}>
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 11, color: '#e2e8f0' }}>CPU</Text>
  <Sparkline data={cpuData} width={60} height={16} color="#ef4444" />
  <Text style={{ fontSize: 11, color: '#94a3b8' }}>72%</Text>
</Box>
```

criticalRules: The `data` prop is required. An empty array renders an empty placeholder.
Sparkline normalizes to the data's own min/max range, not 0-based. If all values are equal, the range defaults to 1, rendering all bars at minimum height.
The component has a fixed size based on `width` and `height`. It does not grow or shrink with its container. The `style` prop can override the container dimensions if needed.
For real-time data, pass a new array reference to `data` on each update. Sparkline re-renders whenever the data array changes.

metadata.title: Switch
metadata.description: A toggle switch with on/off states, providing a sliding thumb on a colored track.

sections.overview:
Switch is a toggle control that slides a thumb along a track to indicate an on/off state. The track changes color based on the current value, and the thumb moves to the left (off) or right (on) edge.

Switch supports both controlled and uncontrolled modes. In controlled mode, pass `value` and respond to `onValueChange`. In uncontrolled mode, omit `value` and optionally set `defaultValue`. On web, the thumb animates with a CSS transition. In native mode, the thumb position is driven by flexbox `justifyContent`.
sections.api:
Import: import { Switch } from '@ilovereact/core';

Usage:
```tsx
<Switch
  value={isEnabled}
  onValueChange={(v) => setIsEnabled(v)}
  trackColor={{ true: '#81b0ff', false: '#767577' }}
/>
```

Props:

| Prop         | Type                                    | Default                                | Description                             |
|--------------|-----------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------|
| value        | boolean                                 | -                                      | Controlled value. Omit for uncontrolled |
| defaultValue | boolean                                 | false                                  | Initial value in uncontrolled mode      |
| onValueChange| (value: boolean) => void                | -                                      | Called when the switch is toggled        |
| disabled     | boolean                                 | false                                  | Disables interaction and dims opacity   |
| style        | Style                                   | -                                      | Container style overrides               |
| trackColor   | { true: Color; false: Color }           | { true: '#81b0ff', false: '#767577' }  | Track colors for on/off states          |
| thumbColor   | Color                                   | '#f4f3f4'                              | Thumb circle color                      |
| width        | number                                  | 50                                     | Total switch width in pixels            |
| height       | number                                  | 28                                     | Total switch height in pixels           |

examples.title: Basic controlled switch
examples.code:
```tsx
const [enabled, setEnabled] = useState(false);

<Switch value={enabled} onValueChange={setEnabled} />
```

examples.title: Uncontrolled with custom colors
Disabled switch
examples.code:
```tsx
<Switch value={true} disabled />
```

criticalRules: Switch has a fixed pixel size. It does not stretch to fill its container by default. The `width` and `height` props control the track dimensions directly.
When `disabled` is true, opacity is set to 0.5 and click/toggle events are ignored.
In controlled mode, the component does not update visually unless the parent updates the `value` prop in response to `onValueChange`.

metadata.title: Table
metadata.description: Data table with configurable columns, alignment, striping, and custom cell renderers.
