metadata.title: Lua Runtime Internals
metadata.description: Complete inventory of all 19 Lua modules that power the Love2D target

sections.overview:
The Lua runtime consists of 19 modules that collectively implement the rendering
pipeline for the Love2D target. The entry point is init.lua, which detects the
operating mode, loads the appropriate bridge, and initializes all submodules. On every
frame, the runtime ticks the JavaScript engine, drains mutation commands, advances
animations, runs layout, and paints the tree.

All Lua files live at lua/ in the monorepo root (source of truth) and are copied into
projects via `make cli-setup` and `ilovereact update`.
sections.api:
Module Inventory:

  init.lua           - Entry point. Detects mode (native/web/canvas), loads all
                       modules, implements love.update/draw/input callbacks.
                       Manages HMR, interaction styles, deferred mount protocol.

  tree.lua           - Retained instance tree. Receives mutation commands from JS
                       (createNode, updateProps, appendChild, removeChild, etc.)
                       and maintains the live node tree. Tracks dirty state.

  layout.lua         - Flexbox layout engine. Computes {x, y, w, h} for every node.
                       Handles flex-grow/shrink, wrap, justify, align, padding,
                       margin, gap, text measurement, min/max clamping.

  painter.lua        - Love2D painter. Walks computed tree and issues love.graphics
                       calls. Handles backgrounds, borders, text, images, shadows,
                       gradients, transforms, opacity, clipping, scrollbars.

  events.lua         - Event handling. Hit testing, hover tracking, drag state,
                       event creation (click, release, keydown, wheel, touch,
                       gamepad), bubble path construction.

  measure.lua        - Text measurement. Font loading/caching by (size, family,
                       weight) tuple. measureText() for layout, getFont() for
                       painter. Letter spacing width calculation.

  bridge_quickjs.lua - QuickJS FFI bridge. Loads libquickjs.so via LuaJIT FFI.
                       eval(), callGlobal(), tick(), drainCommands(), pushEvent().

  bridge_fs.lua      - Module.FS bridge. File-based communication via Emscripten
                       shared filesystem. poll(), flush(), emit().

  animate.lua        - Lua-side transitions and keyframe animations. Processes
                       CSS-style transition declarations and animation keyframes.
                       Interpolates style values per frame.

  images.lua         - Image loading and caching. Manages love.graphics.newImage
                       instances. Handles async loading and placeholder display.

  focus.lua          - Focus manager for Lua-owned inputs (TextEditor). Tracks
                       which node has focus, handles focus/blur transitions.

  texteditor.lua     - Lua-owned multi-line text editor. Handles cursor, selection,
                       line numbers, scrolling, key input, mouse selection.
                       Renders directly via love.graphics calls.

  errors.lua         - Error overlay. Displays runtime errors as a full-screen
                       overlay with stack traces. Uses raw love.graphics calls
                       (independent of the tree/layout system).

  inspector.lua      - Visual inspector (F12). Shows node boundaries, computed
                       dimensions, style properties. Highlights hovered nodes.
                       Displays layout timing and paint timing.

  console.lua        - Interactive eval console (backtick key). Evaluates JS
                       expressions via the bridge and displays results.

  screenshot.lua     - Headless screenshot capture. Waits for the first stable
                       frame, captures the framebuffer, saves as PNG.

  zindex.lua         - Z-index sorting. Returns paint-ordered child lists based
                       on zIndex style property (stable sort, ascending).

  storage.lua        - Persistent storage RPC handlers. Provides get/set/remove
                       methods backed by love.filesystem.

  target_love2d.lua  - Love2D target configuration. Contains target-specific
                       constants and setup.

examples.title: Module Loading Order (Native Mode)
examples.code:
When ReactLove.init() is called in native mode:

  1. resolveBasePath()                  -- Find the lua/ directory
  2. require("lua.bridge_quickjs")      -- Load QuickJS FFI bridge
  3. BridgeQJS.new(libpath)             -- Create bridge with libquickjs.so
  4. require("lua.measure")             -- Text measurement module
  5. require("lua.images")              -- Image cache
  6. require("lua.animate")             -- Animation engine
  7. require("lua.tree")                -- Retained tree
  8. tree.init({ images, animate })     -- Wire dependencies
  9. animate.init({ tree })             -- Wire back-reference
  10. require("lua.layout")             -- Layout engine
  11. layout.init({ measure })          -- Wire text measurement
  12. require("lua.painter")            -- Painter
  13. painter.init({ measure, images }) -- Wire dependencies
  14. require("lua.events")             -- Event system
  15. events.setTreeModule(tree)         -- Wire tree reference
  16. require("lua.texteditor")         -- Text editor
  17. texteditor.init({ measure })      -- Wire measurement
  18. bridge:eval(bundleJS)             -- Load the JS bundle into QuickJS

  Always-loaded (independent, no init):
  - require("lua.errors")              -- Error overlay
  - require("lua.inspector")           -- F12 inspector
  - require("lua.console")             -- Backtick console
  - require("lua.focus")               -- Focus manager

metadata.title: Performance Tips
metadata.description: Optimization strategies for iLoveReact applications

sections.overview:
iLoveReact runs a full layout pass on every frame where the tree is dirty. The layout
engine, text measurement, and painter all have costs that scale with tree size and
complexity. Most applications run comfortably at 60fps, but deeply nested trees, large
text blocks, or unvirtualized long lists can cause frame drops.

The key optimization principle is the same as in any flexbox system: keep the tree
shallow, give the layout engine as much information as possible upfront, and avoid
unnecessary re-computation.

examples.title: Keep Flex Trees Shallow
examples.code:
SLOW: Deep nesting forces the layout engine to resolve more constraints.

  <Box>
    <Box>
      <Box>
        <Box>
          <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>Deeply nested</Text>
        </Box>
      </Box>
    </Box>
  </Box>

FAST: Flat structure with flexDirection row/column does the same layout
in fewer nodes.

  <Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row' }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>Flat and fast</Text>
  </Box>

Each additional nesting level adds layout computation. Prefer
flexDirection: 'row' on a single Box over nested column wrappers.

examples.title: Use FlatList for Long Lists
Use AnimatedValue for Smooth Animations
Pre-Compute Grid Dimensions

criticalRules: Keep flex trees shallow. Every nesting level costs layout time.
Use FlatList for any list longer than ~50 items.
Use AnimatedValue for animations. Do not animate via useState.
Pre-compute dimensions when you know them. Do not rely on child
content to infer container size.
Fill the viewport. Love2D is a fixed canvas, not a scrolling page.
Empty space below content is wasted if you do not set explicit sizes.
Avoid letterSpacing on large text blocks. Character-by-character
rendering is expensive.

metadata.title: Common Errors and Solutions
metadata.description: Symptom-to-solution guide for the most frequent iLoveReact issues

sections.overview:
This page lists the most common errors and unexpected behaviors in iLoveReact, organized
by symptom. Each entry explains why the problem occurs and how to fix it. Most of these
are caught by the static linter (`ilovereact lint`), so running the linter after every
component change is the fastest way to avoid them.

examples.title: Text Not Rendering
examples.code:
Symptom: A <Text> component exists in the tree but nothing appears on screen.

Cause: The Text node is missing an explicit fontSize.
  Without fontSize, the layout engine uses a default of 14 but the linter
  will block your build. If you bypassed the linter, the text may render
  at an unexpected size or position.

Fix: Always provide fontSize on every Text node.

  BAD:  <Text style={{ color: '#ffffff' }}>Hello</Text>
  GOOD: <Text style={{ fontSize: 16, color: '#ffffff' }}>Hello</Text>

The linter rule `no-missing-font-size` enforces this.

examples.title: flexGrow Not Working
examples.code:
Symptom: A node has flexGrow: 1 but does not expand to fill space.

Cause: The parent does not have a known size on the main axis.
  flexGrow distributes free space. If the parent's size is auto (unknown),
  there is no free space to distribute.

Fix: Give the parent an explicit size.

  BAD:
  <Box>
    <Box style={{ flexGrow: 1 }} />  {/* Parent has no height */}
  </Box>

  GOOD:
  <Box style={{ height: '100%' }}>
    <Box style={{ flexGrow: 1 }} />  {/* Parent has known height */}
  </Box>

For the root container, always use width: '100%', height: '100%'.
Do NOT use flexGrow: 1 on root containers.

examples.title: justifyContent Ignored on Row
examples.code:
Symptom: A row Box has justifyContent: 'center' but children are left-aligned.

Cause: The row Box has no explicit width. Box nodes have no intrinsic width
  (only Text nodes do via measurement). Without a known width, there is no
  space to distribute, so justifyContent has no effect.

Fix: Add width: '100%' or a fixed width to row Boxes that need justifyContent.

  BAD:
  <Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row', justifyContent: 'center' }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>Centered?</Text>
  </Box>

  GOOD:
  <Box style={{ flexDirection: 'row', width: '100%', justifyContent: 'center' }}>
    <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>Centered!</Text>
  </Box>

examples.title: Mixed Text Children
examples.code:
Symptom: Text content renders incorrectly or only partially.

Cause: Using mixed JSX expressions in Text creates multiple child nodes
  instead of a single text string.

Fix: Use template literals for dynamic text content.

  BAD:  <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>Count: {count}</Text>
  GOOD: <Text style={{ fontSize: 14 }}>{`Count: ${count}`}</Text>

examples.title: Build Fails
examples.code:
Symptom: `ilovereact build` exits with errors.

Cause: The build command runs `ilovereact lint` as a gate before bundling.
  Layout lint errors will block the build.

Fix: Run `ilovereact lint` separately to see all errors. Fix each one.
  Common lint errors:
  - no-missing-font-size: Text without fontSize
  - no-block-char-in-text: Unicode block character in Text (use Box with backgroundColor)
  - root container without 100% dimensions

If a lint rule is wrong for your use case, use the escape hatch:
  // ilr-ignore-next-line

examples.title: Runtime Files Outdated
examples.code:
Symptom: After editing framework files (lua/*.lua, packages/shared/), the changes
  do not appear in your project.

Cause: You edited the source of truth but did not run the sync pipeline.
  The project still has the old copies.

Fix: Run the full sync pipeline.

  make cli-setup              # source -> cli/runtime/
  cd examples/<project>
  ilovereact update           # cli/runtime/ -> project copies
  ilovereact build dist:love  # rebuild

examples.title: libquickjs.so Not Found
examples.code:
Symptom: Love2D crashes with an error about loading libquickjs.so.

Cause: The QuickJS shared library has not been built or is not in the
  expected location.

Fix: Build QuickJS and sync to the project.

  make setup       # Clone quickjs-ng, compile libquickjs.so
  make cli-setup   # Copy to cli/runtime/lib/
  cd examples/<project>
  ilovereact update  # Copy to project/lib/

criticalRules: Run `ilovereact lint` after EVERY component change.
The linter catches the most common errors before they become runtime bugs.
When in doubt, check the computed layout with the F12 inspector.
If changes are not appearing, check whether you edited the source of truth
or a copy.

metadata.title: FAQ
metadata.description: Frequently asked questions about iLoveReact capabilities, limitations, and workflows

sections.overview:
This page answers the most frequently asked questions about iLoveReact. If your question
is not here, check the common errors page for specific error symptoms, or the debugging
page for runtime investigation tools.

examples.title: Can I use npm packages?
examples.code:
Q: Can I install and use npm packages in my iLoveReact app?

A: Yes. Your src/ directory is a standard TypeScript/React project. Install packages
with `npm install` and import them normally. The esbuild bundler resolves and bundles
npm dependencies into the output.

Note: For the Love2D target, the bundle runs inside QuickJS, which has no Node.js
APIs (no fs, no http, no child_process). Pure JavaScript packages work. Packages
that depend on Node.js built-ins will not work in Love2D native mode but will work
in web mode or grid targets (which run on Node.js).

examples.title: How do I debug on Love2D?
examples.code:
Q: How do I inspect my UI layout at runtime on Love2D?

A: Press F12 to open the visual inspector. It overlays node boundaries, computed
dimensions, and style properties on your live UI. Move your mouse over elements to
see their layout data. Press F12 again to close.

For evaluating expressions at runtime, press the backtick key (`) to open the
interactive console. Type JavaScript expressions and see results inline.

examples.title: How does hot reload work?
examples.code:
Q: How do I see my changes without restarting Love2D?

A: Use `ilovereact dev` in one terminal (watch mode, rebuilds bundle.js on change)
and `love .` in another terminal. The Lua runtime polls bundle.js every ~1 second.
When it detects a change, it:
  1. Reads dev state from JS (__getDevState)
  2. Destroys the QuickJS context
  3. Clears all Lua-side state (tree, images, animations, hover, focus)
  4. Creates a new QuickJS context
  5. Loads the new bundle
  6. Injects cached dev state (__devState)
  7. Triggers mount

This gives you near-instant reload without restarting Love2D.

examples.title: What React version is required?
examples.code:
Q: What version of React does iLoveReact use?

A: React 18.3+ with react-reconciler 0.29. The reconciler version must match
the React version. iLoveReact uses React's concurrent features where applicable.

examples.title: Can I use CSS?
examples.code:
Q: Can I use CSS stylesheets, CSS modules, or Tailwind CSS?

A: No. iLoveReact uses Style objects with flexbox properties, not CSS. The Style
interface is defined in TypeScript and supports a subset of CSS flexbox properties
plus custom properties for the target renderers.

In web mode, Style objects are converted to React CSSProperties by the styleToCSS()
function. But you write Style objects, not CSS.

There is no CSS cascade, no class selectors, no media queries, and no CSS variables.
All styling is explicit and co-located with components.

examples.title: How does text measurement work?
examples.code:
Q: How does iLoveReact know how wide text is?

A: On Love2D, text measurement uses Love2D's font:getWrap() and font:getWidth()
APIs. The measure.lua module loads fonts by (size, family, weight) and caches
them. When the layout engine encounters a Text node without explicit dimensions,
it calls measureText() to get the intrinsic width and height based on the font
metrics and the available width constraint.

On web, the browser's own text measurement is used (via CSS).

On grid targets, text width equals the character count (monospace grids).

examples.title: Can I mix targets?
examples.code:
Q: Can I render the same component to multiple targets simultaneously?

A: Each build is target-specific. You cannot render to Love2D and a terminal
from the same running process. However, shared components (those that only use
Box, Text, Pressable, and standard Style properties) work across all targets
without modification.

The recommended approach: write your components in a shared package, then
create target-specific entry points that import and render them.

seeAlso: common-errors.txt - Specific error messages and fixes

metadata.title: Complete Style Property Reference
metadata.description: Every property in the Style interface with types, valid values, and descriptions

sections.overview:
The Style interface defines all visual and layout properties for iLoveReact nodes. It is
passed via the `style` prop on Box, Text, Image, and other components. All properties
are optional. Properties that are not set use their default values (typically 0, 'column',
or undefined).

Colors can be CSS hex strings ("#ff0000", "#ff000080" with alpha), CSS function notation
("rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)"), or Love2D-style number arrays [r, g, b, a] where each value
is 0-1.
sections.api:
--- SIZING ---

width?: number | string
  Width of the node. Number = pixels. String = percentage ("50%"), viewport ("10vw").
  Default: Inherits parent's width for non-text nodes. Text nodes auto-size.

height?: number | string
  Height of the node. Number = pixels. String = percentage, viewport ("5vh").
  Default: Auto-sizes to content.

minWidth?: number | string
  Minimum width constraint. Applied after flex distribution.
  Default: none

minHeight?: number | string
  Minimum height constraint. Applied after flex distribution.
  Default: none

maxWidth?: number | string
  Maximum width constraint. Applied after flex distribution.
  Default: none

maxHeight?: number | string
  Maximum height constraint. Applied after flex distribution.
  Default: none

aspectRatio?: number
  Width-to-height ratio. When one dimension is set, the other is computed.
  Example: aspectRatio: 16/9 means width = height * (16/9).
  Default: none

--- FLEXBOX ---

display?: 'flex' | 'none'
  'flex': Normal layout participation (default).
  'none': Node and all descendants skipped entirely from layout and painting.
  Default: 'flex'

flexDirection?: 'row' | 'column'
  Main axis direction. 'column' stacks children vertically. 'row' lays out horizontally.
  Default: 'column'

flexWrap?: 'nowrap' | 'wrap'
  'nowrap': All children on one line (default). 'wrap': Children wrap to next line.
  Default: 'nowrap'

justifyContent?: 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'space-between' | 'space-around' | 'space-evenly'
  Distribution of children along the main axis.
  Only effective when the container has a known main-axis size.
  Default: 'start'

alignItems?: 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'stretch'
  Alignment of children along the cross axis.
  'stretch': Children expand to fill the cross axis (unless they have explicit size).
  Default: 'stretch'

alignSelf?: 'auto' | 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | 'stretch'
  Per-child override of the parent's alignItems.
  'auto': Use parent's alignItems value.
  Default: 'auto'

flexGrow?: number
  Proportion of positive free space to absorb. Only works when the parent has
  definite main-axis size and there is leftover space after placing all children.
  Default: 0

flexShrink?: number
  Proportion of negative overflow to absorb. Activated when children overflow
  the parent's main axis. CSS default is 1 (items shrink proportionally).
  Default: 1

flexBasis?: number | string | 'auto'
  Initial main-axis size before flex distribution. Takes priority over width/height.
  'auto': Falls back to width (row) or height (column).
  Default: 'auto'

gap?: number | string
  Space between children on the main axis AND between lines when wrapping.
  Applied between items only (not before the first or after the last).
  Default: 0

--- SPACING ---

padding?: number | string
  Inner space on all four sides. Percentage resolves against the node's width.
  Default: 0

paddingLeft?: number | string
  Left inner space. Overrides padding for the left side.

paddingRight?: number | string
  Right inner space. Overrides padding for the right side.

paddingTop?: number | string
  Top inner space. Overrides padding for the top side.

paddingBottom?: number | string
  Bottom inner space. Overrides padding for the bottom side.

margin?: number | string
  Outer space on all four sides. Percentage resolves against the parent's width.
  Default: 0

marginLeft?: number | string
  Left outer space. Overrides margin for the left side.

marginRight?: number | string
  Right outer space. Overrides margin for the right side.

marginTop?: number | string
  Top outer space. Overrides margin for the top side.

marginBottom?: number | string
  Bottom outer space. Overrides margin for the bottom side.

--- VISUAL ---

backgroundColor?: Color
  Fill color for Box/View nodes. Hex string, rgba string, or [r,g,b,a] array.
  Default: transparent

borderRadius?: number
  Uniform corner radius in pixels. Applied to all four corners.
  Default: 0

borderTopLeftRadius?: number
  Per-corner override. Takes precedence over borderRadius.

borderTopRightRadius?: number
  Per-corner override. Takes precedence over borderRadius.

borderBottomLeftRadius?: number
  Per-corner override. Takes precedence over borderRadius.

borderBottomRightRadius?: number
  Per-corner override. Takes precedence over borderRadius.

borderWidth?: number
  Uniform border stroke width on all sides.
  Default: 0

borderTopWidth?: number
  Per-side border width. Overrides borderWidth for the top side.

borderRightWidth?: number
  Per-side border width. Overrides borderWidth for the right side.

borderBottomWidth?: number
  Per-side border width. Overrides borderWidth for the bottom side.

borderLeftWidth?: number
  Per-side border width. Overrides borderWidth for the left side.

borderColor?: Color
  Uniform border color on all sides.
  Default: gray (0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1)

borderTopColor?: Color
  Per-side border color. Overrides borderColor for the top side.

borderRightColor?: Color
  Per-side border color. Overrides borderColor for the right side.

borderBottomColor?: Color
  Per-side border color. Overrides borderColor for the bottom side.

borderLeftColor?: Color
  Per-side border color. Overrides borderColor for the left side.

overflow?: 'visible' | 'hidden' | 'scroll'
  'visible': Content can extend beyond bounds (default).
  'hidden': Content clipped to bounds (stencil for rounded, scissor for rectangular).
  'scroll': Scrollable container with clipping and scroll indicators.
  Default: 'visible'

opacity?: number
  Node opacity (0-1). Multiplies with inherited opacity from parent chain.
  0 = fully transparent. 1 = fully opaque.
  Default: 1

zIndex?: number
  Paint order within the parent's children. Higher values paint on top.
  Does NOT affect layout, only paint order.
  Default: 0

scrollX?: number
  Horizontal scroll position for scroll containers (controlled mode).

scrollY?: number
  Vertical scroll position for scroll containers (controlled mode).

--- SHADOW ---

shadowColor?: Color
  Box shadow color. Shadow only renders when shadowBlur > 0.

shadowOffsetX?: number
  Horizontal shadow offset in pixels.
  Default: 0

shadowOffsetY?: number
  Vertical shadow offset in pixels.
  Default: 0

shadowBlur?: number
  Shadow blur radius. Simulated by rendering multiple fading rectangles.
  Capped at 10 blur steps for performance.
  Default: 0

--- GRADIENT ---

backgroundGradient?: { direction, colors }
  Linear gradient background. Takes precedence over backgroundColor.
  direction: 'horizontal' | 'vertical' | 'diagonal'
  colors: [Color, Color] -- start and end colors
  Rendered via Love2D mesh API on Love2D, CSS linear-gradient on web.

--- TRANSFORM ---

transform?: { translateX?, translateY?, rotate?, scaleX?, scaleY?, skewX?, skewY?, originX?, originY? }
  Visual transform. Does NOT affect layout or hit testing.
  translateX/Y: Pixel offset.
  rotate: Degrees (not radians).
  scaleX/Y: Scale factor (1 = no scale).
  skewX/Y: Skew angle in degrees.
  originX/Y: Transform origin as 0-1 fraction (0.5 = center, default).

--- TEXT ---

color?: Color
  Text color. Applied to Text and __TEXT__ nodes.
  Inherited by __TEXT__ children from parent Text nodes.
  Default: white (1, 1, 1, 1)

fontSize?: number
  Font size in pixels. REQUIRED on all Text nodes (enforced by linter).
  Inherited by __TEXT__ children from parent Text nodes.
  Default: 14 (but the linter requires explicit values)

fontFamily?: string
  Path to a .ttf or .otf font file. Relative to the Love2D filesystem root.
  Inherited by __TEXT__ children from parent Text nodes.
  Default: Love2D default font

fontWeight?: 'normal' | 'bold' | number
  Font weight. 'bold' triggers faux-bold rendering (double draw with offset).
  Default: 'normal'

textAlign?: 'left' | 'center' | 'right'
  Horizontal text alignment within the node's computed width.
  Default: 'left'

textOverflow?: 'clip' | 'ellipsis'
  How to handle text that overflows the node's width.
  'ellipsis': Truncate with "..." at the end.
  Default: 'clip'

textDecorationLine?: 'none' | 'underline' | 'line-through'
  Text decoration line style.
  Default: 'none'

lineHeight?: number
  Line height in pixels. Overrides the font's natural line height.
  When set, text is rendered line-by-line with this spacing.
  Default: Font's natural line height

letterSpacing?: number
  Extra space between characters in pixels.
  WARNING: Activates character-by-character rendering. Expensive on large text.
  Default: 0

--- TEXT SHADOW ---

textShadowColor?: Color
  Text shadow color. Shadow only renders when this is set.

textShadowOffsetX?: number
  Horizontal text shadow offset.
  Default: 0

textShadowOffsetY?: number
  Vertical text shadow offset.
  Default: 0

--- IMAGE ---

objectFit?: 'fill' | 'contain' | 'cover' | 'none'
  How the image scales within its bounds.
  'fill': Stretch to fill (default). 'contain': Fit inside, letterbox.
  'cover': Fill, crop overflow. 'none': No scaling, center.
  Default: 'fill'

--- POSITIONING ---

position?: 'relative' | 'absolute'
  'relative': Normal flow (default).
  'absolute': Positioned relative to the nearest positioned ancestor.
  Default: 'relative'

top?: number | string
  Offset from the top edge (absolute positioning).

bottom?: number | string
  Offset from the bottom edge (absolute positioning).

left?: number | string
  Offset from the left edge (absolute positioning).

right?: number | string
  Offset from the right edge (absolute positioning).

--- VISIBILITY ---

visibility?: 'visible' | 'hidden'
  'visible': Normal rendering (default).
  'hidden': Node is not painted, but still occupies layout space.
  Unlike display:'none', children of a hidden node still paint.
  Default: 'visible'

--- OUTLINE ---

outlineColor?: Color
  Outline color. Drawn outside the border box.
  Default: white (1, 1, 1, 1) or currentColor on web

outlineWidth?: number
  Outline stroke width.
  Default: 0

outlineOffset?: number
  Gap between the border box and the outline.
  Default: 0

--- TRANSITION ---

transition?: { [property: string]: { duration?, easing?, delay? } }
  CSS-style transitions. Lua-side: JS declares transition targets, Lua interpolates.
  Web-side: Mapped directly to CSS transition property.

  Per-property: transition: { backgroundColor: { duration: 300, easing: 'easeInOut' } }
  All properties: transition: { all: { duration: 300 } }

  duration: number in milliseconds (default: 300)
  easing: 'linear' | 'easeIn' | 'easeOut' | 'easeInOut' | 'bounce' | 'elastic' (default: 'easeInOut')
  delay: number in milliseconds (default: 0)

--- ANIMATION ---

animation?: { keyframes, duration?, easing?, iterations?, direction?, fillMode?, delay?, playState? }
  CSS-style keyframe animations. Runs on the Lua side.

  keyframes: { [percentage: number]: Partial<Style> }
    Percentage keys from 0 to 100. Each value is a partial Style object.
    Example: { 0: { opacity: 0 }, 100: { opacity: 1 } }

  duration: number in milliseconds (default: 300)
  easing: string easing function name (default: 'linear')
  iterations: number, -1 = infinite (default: 1)
  direction: 'normal' | 'reverse' | 'alternate' | 'alternate-reverse' (default: 'normal')
  fillMode: 'none' | 'forwards' | 'backwards' | 'both' (default: 'none')
  delay: number in milliseconds (default: 0)
  playState: 'running' | 'paused' (default: 'running')

metadata.title: TypeScript Types Reference
metadata.description: Complete TypeScript type definitions for all iLoveReact interfaces

sections.overview:
This reference lists all TypeScript types exported from @ilovereact/core (packages/shared).
Types are organized by category: core types, primitive component props, higher-level
component props, animation types, and utility types. All types are importable from
'@ilovereact/core'.
sections.api:
--- CORE TYPES ---

Color = string | [number, number, number, number?]
  CSS string ("#ff0000", "rgba(255,0,0,0.5)") or Love2D array [r, g, b, a] (0-1 range).
  The alpha channel is optional and defaults to 1.

Style
  Full style interface. See style-properties.txt for every property.
  All properties are optional.

RendererMode = 'web' | 'native'
  Which rendering path the primitives use.
  'web': DOM elements (div/span/img).
  'native': Host elements for react-reconciler (View/Text/Image).

--- EVENT TYPE ---

LoveEvent
  type: string
  targetId?: number
  x?: number
  y?: number
  button?: number
  key?: string
  scancode?: string

metadata.title: Animation Examples
metadata.description: Demonstrates timing, spring, composite, and CSS-style animations in iLoveReact

sections.overview:
This example demonstrates the iLoveReact animation system. It covers three approaches:
imperative animations via AnimatedValue (timing and spring), convenience hooks
(useSpring, useTransition), and declarative CSS-style animations (style.transition and
style.animation). The example shows how to create smooth motion without causing React
re-renders on every frame.
sections.explanation:
1. FadeInBox uses useAnimation to get an AnimatedValue and its current numeric
   value. The timing animation runs once on mount, easing opacity from 0 to 1
   over 1 second. The component re-renders only when the batched value changes.

2. SpringBox uses the useSpring convenience hook. When the target value changes
   (80 to 150 or back), a spring animation automatically starts. The stiffness
   and damping parameters control the spring's feel (bouncy vs smooth).

3. CompositeBox demonstrates parallel, sequence, and loop. First, X and Y
   animations run in parallel (diagonal move). Then scale animates up and down
   in sequence. The whole thing loops infinitely.

4. TransitionBox uses CSS-style transitions. The transition property on the style
   declares that backgroundColor should animate over 300ms with easeInOut easing.
   The hoverStyle provides the target value. The Lua animate module handles
   interpolation when the hover state changes (0-frame latency, no JS round-trip).

5. PulseBox uses CSS-style keyframe animation. The animation property declares
   keyframes at 0%, 50%, and 100%, with infinite iterations. The Lua animate
   module runs this entirely on the Lua side, no React re-renders needed.

6. Key performance insight: useAnimation and useSpring batch updates to animation
   frames. AnimatedValue listeners fire every frame, but React state updates are
   debounced. CSS-style animations (transition/animation) run entirely in Lua
   without any React involvement.

metadata.title: Interactive Counter
metadata.description: A counter app with increment and decrement buttons using useState and Pressable

sections.overview:
This example builds an interactive counter with two buttons. It demonstrates React state
management (useState), user interaction (Pressable with render props for press feedback),
row layout (flexDirection: 'row' with explicit width), and the template literal pattern
for dynamic text content.
sections.explanation:
1. The Button component uses Pressable with a render prop: ({ pressed }) => ...
   This gives access to the pressed state for visual feedback (darker blue when
   pressed).

2. Each button has fixed width: 64, height: 64 for a square shape. The buttons
   use borderRadius: 12 for rounded corners.

3. The counter display uses a template literal: {`${count}`}. This is important.
   Do NOT write {count} as it creates a number child node. Always wrap dynamic
   content in template literals for Text nodes.

4. The button row has flexDirection: 'row' and width: '100%'. The width is critical:
   without it, justifyContent: 'center' has no effect because the row Box has no
   known width to distribute space within.

5. gap: 20 adds 20 pixels of space between the two buttons.

6. gap: 32 on the root container adds space between the counter text and the
   button row.

7. fontWeight: 'bold' on the button text triggers faux-bold rendering (the text
   is drawn twice with a slight offset on Love2D).

metadata.title: Multi-Panel Dashboard
metadata.description: A dashboard layout with navigation, content panels, and data visualization components

sections.overview:
This example builds a multi-panel dashboard layout using higher-level components from
@ilovereact/core. It demonstrates NavPanel for navigation, Tabs for content switching,
Card for content containers, Table for data display, ProgressBar for metrics, and
Badge for status indicators. This is a realistic application layout that exercises
the flexbox system with nested containers.
sections.explanation:
1. The root layout is a row (flexDirection: 'row') splitting the viewport into a
   NavPanel on the left (fixed 180px width, default) and a content area (flexGrow: 1).

2. NavPanel renders a sidebar with section headers and selectable items. The
   activeId prop controls which item is highlighted. onSelect updates the state.

3. Tabs provide content switching within the main panel. The 'underline' variant
   (default) renders an underline indicator on the active tab.

4. MetricCard is a custom component wrapping Card. Each card uses flexGrow: 1 to
   distribute equally across the row. The row has width: '100%' and gap: 12.

5. Table renders a data grid with columns and rows. The striped prop alternates
   row backgrounds for readability.

6. ProgressBar shows a visual progress indicator. The value prop is 0-1 range.
   showLabel displays the percentage text.

7. The content area uses padding: 16 and gap: 16 to space all its children
   evenly. This avoids manual margin management on each child.

metadata.title: Hello World
metadata.description: The simplest possible iLoveReact application - a centered greeting

sections.overview:
This example demonstrates the absolute minimum iLoveReact application: a single Text
node centered on a full-viewport Box. It covers the three essential concepts: importing
primitives, filling the viewport, and centering content with flexbox.
sections.explanation:
1. Import Box and Text from @ilovereact/core. These are the universal primitives
   that work on every target.

2. The root Box has width: '100%' and height: '100%'. This is required to fill the
   viewport. Without these, the root Box has zero size and nothing renders.

3. backgroundColor: '#0f172a' sets a dark blue background. Colors are CSS hex strings.

4. justifyContent: 'center' centers children along the main axis (vertical, because
   the default flexDirection is 'column').

5. alignItems: 'center' centers children along the cross axis (horizontal).

6. The Text node has an explicit fontSize: 32. Every Text node MUST have fontSize.
   This is enforced by the linter.

7. color: '#f8fafc' sets the text color to near-white.

metadata.title: Todo List App
metadata.description: A todo list with add and remove functionality using TextInput, FlatList, and state management

sections.overview:
This example builds a complete todo list application. It demonstrates text input handling
(TextInput with onSubmit), list rendering (mapping over state), dynamic state updates
(adding and removing items), and scroll containers for overflow content.
sections.explanation:
1. TextInput with onSubmit handles adding new todos. When the user presses Enter,
   onSubmit fires with the current text value. The input clears automatically.

2. ScrollView wraps the todo list so it scrolls when items overflow the container.
   It has flexGrow: 1 to fill remaining vertical space (the parent has height: '100%').

3. Each TodoItem is a row (flexDirection: 'row') with three elements: a toggle
   circle, the todo text (with flexGrow: 1 to fill space), and a remove button.

4. The toggle circle uses conditional rendering: {todo.done && ...} to show a
   checkmark only when the todo is completed.

5. textDecorationLine: 'line-through' adds a strikethrough on completed todos.

6. Unicode characters (\u2713 for checkmark, \u00d7 for multiplication sign)
   are used for icons. In iLoveReact there are no icon fonts, so Unicode or
   Image components are the icon options.

7. State is managed with useState and useCallback. The functional update pattern
   (prev => ...) ensures correct state transitions when events fire rapidly.
